1 INTRODUCTION
1.1     Background
1.1.1   Highways England (formerly the Highways Agency) owns and operates an
        extensive range of Electronic Motorway Display Equipment on its motorways
        and All-Purpose Trunk Roads and these are currently used to provide both
        mandatory (e.g. speed limits) and advisory information to motorists.
1.1.2   As part of an initiative to become 'easier to do business with' and to become
        more open to offers from a broader range of suppliers of the most reliable
        and most energy-efficient equipment, Highways England has embarked
        upon a process of redrafting its technical requirements in a less prescriptive
        and more performance-based style and to align with European Standards.
1.1.3   As one of the outputs of that initiative, this specification defines the generic
        performance requirements for Highways England Electronic Motorway
        Display Equipment.      The requirements related to particular Display
        Equipment types are given in the appendices.
1.1.4   This specification shall be read in conjunction with:
                BS EN 12966: Road vertical signs - Variable message traffic signs
                TR2608: Control and Interface Specification for Electronic Motorway
                 Display Equipment
                TR1100:     General Technical         Requirements     for   Motorway
                 Communications Equipment.

1.2     Scope and Purpose
1.2.1   BS EN 12966 is the European Standard for variable message traffic signs.
1.2.2   BS EN 12966 requires manufacturers to “CE” mark their Products and
        provide a Declaration of Performance (DoP) with the performance classes
        defined, including those related to the Construction Products Directive
        (89/106/EEC)
1.2.3   This specification describes:
                The performance classes that are required
                A generic set of performance requirements for Electronic Motorway
                 Display Equipment for characteristics not covered by BS EN 12966
                The requirements related to the Structural Design Statement
                 process required for manufacturers to verify that their
                 Equipment can be safely supported by the host infrastructure and to
                 achieve Highways England Technical Approval Authority (TAA)
                 approval (Appendix B)
                The specific requirements for particular Display Equipment types,
                 including the interfaces they shall be compatible with on their
                 mounting structures in the Appendices D to J

2 NATIONAL REQUIREMENTS
2.1     General
2.1.1   This section outlines the UK National performance requirements for
        Electronic Motorway Display Equipment.
2.1.2   The purpose of Electronic Motorway Display Equipment is to allow traffic
        control centres to provide complete and clear displays of mandatory and
        advisory information in a timely, safe, reliable and consistent manner, in all
        weather conditions, thus contributing to the safe and efficient use of the
        roads. To achieve this, Electronic Motorway Display Equipment shall:
                Respond to incoming commands from traffic control centres and
                 action them
                Monitor and report its operational and fault status so traffic control
                 centres can determine when Equipment is unlikely to be able to set a
                 display, if requested.
                Switch off displays when performance falls below the required
                 performance level
                Provide locally measured ambient light levels, when configured to do
                 so.
2.1.3   Across the range of Equipment currently defined, display types include the
        following, as defined in the appendices for each Equipment type:
                Aspects (e.g. advisory or mandatory speed            limits; symbols
                 representing lane closure)
                Text Messages
                Pictograms (e.g. roadworks symbol)
                Other Legends (e.g. Junction layouts)
2.1.4   New display types may also be specified by Purchasers, within the
        performance requirements of this Specification.
2.1.5   The Display Equipment covered by this specification will usually be installed
        on gantry structures that are described by reference to BD51/14, but may
        also be installed on posts at the roadside at some locations. To assist in
        minimising Mean Time to Repair and the need for working at height, certain
        interfaces shall be accessible from a roadside cabinet, as described in more
        detail in TR2608.
2.1.6   The Equipment and its operating software shall comply with TR1100 in
        respect of all characteristics and provisions that are not already covered
        under BS EN 12966. Supporting documentation shall be provided as part of
        a Technical File as described by TR1100.

2.1.7   Some Equipment may be used in conjunction with a Speed Enforcement
        System (HA Digital Enforcement and Compliance System Version 3 -
        HADECS3), which monitors Equipment settings using image processing
        techniques:
                   Speed Enforcement Systems requires Home Office Type Approval in
                    accordance with The Speedmeter Handbook
                   Speed Enforcement Systems type testing includes tests carried out
                    together with the Equipment covered by this specification
                   Manufacturers shall ensure that any Display Equipment that is to be
                    used in conjunction with Speed Enforcement Equipment is tested for
                    compatibility with that Speed Enforcement Equipment before that
                    Display Equipment is deployed.
2.1.8   The Equipment shall be compatible with the electrical, communications and
        structural interfaces provided, as described herein.

2.2     System Performance
2.2.1   Highways England requires that all Equipment installed at a given location
        shall operate simultaneously via the standard communications interfaces
        provided, as described further in section 2.4 and Appendix B, without
        degradation.
2.2.2   The system performance criteria is defined below, for the following
        Equipment limits:
                    16 No. single address devices operating via the Signals Sub-
                     System
                       PLUS
                    2 No. additional devices, which may be either:
                       o Multiple address devices operating via the Signals Sub-
                         System and Message Sign Sub-System OR
                       o Single address devices operating via the Message Sign Sub-
                         System
                       PLUS
                    1 No. 'Externally Visible' Ambient Light Monitor (ALM), where
                     required: this may be a physically separate device or use sensors
                     within Display Equipment, if provided.
2.2.3   All Equipment installed at a given location shall be                capable    of
        simultaneously operating under the following conditions:
                   Receiving control messages requiring the setting of their Aspect/
                    Text Message/ Pictograms/ Legend displays (as appropriate to their
                    type), with any associated Lanterns displays, at a frequency of every
                    five seconds

       Performing all background monitoring and testing tasks on a
                    continual basis to enable all control source messages to be
                    responded to correctly during the intervening periods
                   Responding to requests for Ambient Light Monitor (ALM) sensor
                    readings at a maximum frequency of once every five seconds
                   Achieving the above with a minimum of 67% spare capacity in both
                    processor cycles and memory, to allow for future upgrades.
           Note: In case that a requested setting cannot be displayed as a result
           of a fault condition, the control source may request an alternative setting
           immediately.
2.2.4   The maximum 'response time' between the receipt of the final bit of control
        message requesting a setting being received at the main control interface
        and the requested display being set shall not exceed one second provided
        display cell faults remain within displayable thresholds.
2.2.5   Maximum permissible power consumption is specified for each Equipment
        type in the appendices.       Whole-life energy consumption shall be
        competitively compared in supply tenders where reduced consumption may
        offer an advantage.

2.5     Electrical Interfaces
2.5.1   With the exception of any separate ALM device that may be provided, the
        Equipment shall operate via a nominal 230V a.c. mains supply within the
        maximum power consumption limits stated in the appendices.
2.5.2   Standard Highways England power connectors will be provided for Display
        Equipment as part of the standard Highways England cabling infrastructure.
        These may be either Type 1 or Type 2, depending upon the Equipment type,
        as described in Table 2.5 below:

2.5.3   Where the Equipment supplied is not directly compatible with these power
        connectors, adapters may be provided. Alternatively, subject to agreement
        with Highways England in both equipment purchasing and scheme design
        functions, alternative Low Voltage power supply arrangements will not be
        precluded provided that clearly different connector types are used to avoid
        confusion.
2.5.4   The standard provisions within Highways Agency roadside cabinets include
        an electrical supply via a Power Distribution Unit or Consumer Unit or
        similar.    Unless otherwise agreed, any Equipment installed within the
        roadside cabinet shall be supplied with a single 'flying' mains lead 2m long
        for direct connection to this supply. The total maximum power consumption
        should not exceed 100VA.
2.5.5   An equipotential bonding conductor terminated in an M8 ring terminal will
        provided at each Equipment location, including within the roadside cabinet,
        as part of the infrastructure.
2.5.6   All Equipment shall comply with the Power Factor requirements of TR1100.
2.5.7    Nuisance Tripping’ (the unnecessary operation of automatic over-current
        protection devices e.g. RCDs; MCBs) due to external factors is a problem in
        a motorway environment, especially where it is not possible to readily
        access the Equipment to reset the device. Disconnection devices that
        require manual resetting shall not be used within Display Equipment
        enclosures for accessibility reasons.

2.6     Equipment Configuration
2.6.1   The types, electronic addresses, numbers and general configurations of
        Equipment installed at any site location shall be determined via data held
        within a single Equipment Configuration Plug (ECP) Type 9300 to
        MCE1137, as described further in TR2608.
                Due to nature of the multi-drop connections, individual, single
                 address devices operating via the Signals Sub-System will each
                 require a means of setting their local address from outside of the
                 Signal enclosure. Additional standard ECPs may be used for this
                 purpose, if preferred. However, legacy arrangements will not be
                 precluded.
2.6.2   The Equipment shall be 'user-configurable' as defined in TR2608.

2.7     Initialisation
2.7.1   To ensure compatibility with the Highways England control system. the
        Equipment shall perform an Initialisation sequence on ‘Power Up’ and on
        ‘Reset’ in accordance with TR2608.

2.8     Display Setting
2.8.1   Displays (including any Lanterns and Red Rings) shall be set, synchronised
        and monitored by the Equipment when requested by the Signals or
        Message Sign Sub-Systems, in accordance with TR2608.

2.9      Flashing Lanterns
2.9.1    For Display Equipment which requires physically separate or discreet
         Lanterns (see appendices), Lanterns shall be capable of being displayed
         and cleared independently of other parts of the display.
2.9.2    Colours for physically separate or discreet Red and Amber (Yellow)
         Lanterns shall be as defined for Traffic Signals in BS EN 12368 (equivalent
         to colour performance class C2 in BS EN 12966)
2.9.3    The on-axis luminous intensity of physically separate or discreet Lanterns
         shall meet performance class 2/1 of BS EN 12368.
2.9.4    The luminous intensity distribution of physically separate or discreet Red
         Lanterns shall meet that defined in Table 4: Medium wide beam signal (Type
         M) as defined in BS EN 12368.
2.9.5    The luminous intensity distribution of physically separate or discreet Amber
         (Yellow) Lanterns shall meet TR2516 Performance Specification for
         Discontinuous Variable Message Signs.
2.9.6    The optical performance of Lanterns formed from display cells that are part
         of the main display shall meet the performance classes stated in section 2.3.

2.10     Red Rings
2.10.1   For Display Equipment which requires discreet Red Rings (see appendices),
         Red Rings shall be capable of being displayed and cleared independently of
         other parts of the display.

2.11     Luminance Control
2.11.1   Display Equipment shall adjust display Luminance to comply with the
         Luminance Ratio requirements by either:
                Using ambient luminance levels provided within control system
                 messages
                Using ambient luminance levels measured locally by sensors
                 included within the Display Equipment or a separate ALM.
2.11.2   A minimum of 5 levels of signal/sign display luminance shall be provided.
           Note: It is anticipated that an increased number of levels would be
           required to achieve compliance with the luminance/luminance ratio
           requirements of BS EN 12966 with optimal energy efficiency.
2.11.3   For discreet Lanterns, a minimum of 2 levels of Lantern luminance shall be
         provided, with the ‘Dim’ level representing between 15-20% of the ‘Bright’
         Luminance level.
2.11.4   Luminance levels shall be reconfigurable as described in TR2068.
2.11.5   Further details on luminance control are given in TR2608.

2.12     Background Tests (Monitoring) and Fault Reporting
2.12.1   The Equipment shall perform background testing (monitoring) and respond
         to fault conditions in accordance with TR2608.
                In future Highways England may competitively compare equipment
                 fault reports in supply tenders and unreliable or spurious fault
                 reporting may be disadvantageous.
2.12.2   Display cell tests shall not be visible to the casual observer, day or night.
2.12.3   Display cells shall be deemed to be faulty when the number of functional
         emitters in that display cell falls below 50%.
2.12.4   Operational and Fault logs shall be maintained and available for download
         via the interface facilities located in the roadside cabinet and remotely via
         the diagnostics available over the control network connection.
2.12.5   The Equipment shall additionally support SNMP-based fault alarm reporting
         in accordance with TR2608 and TR2597 Generic Roadside Device
         Requirements for Remote Access (Phase 2).

2.13     Reliability and Maintenance
2.13.1   All Equipment shall be designed for a minimum expected in-service life of 15
         years without routine cleaning and with minimum routine maintenance to
         align with Highways England operation, maintenance and renewal
         programmes.
                However, to align with structural requirements and to provide
                 flexibility in future renewal programming, Display Equipment
                 enclosures shall be designed to retain full structural integrity for 30
                 years, without maintenance.
                It is accepted, however, that any prolonged period of service beyond
                 the expected 15 year service life may be subject to extensive
                 refurbishment, including maintenance of any paint system applied to
                 the enclosure.
2.13.2   Some Display Equipment is required to be capable of being maintained to a
         3rd Line Level in situ (i.e. in their place of installation), whereas others will
         be removed and returned to the manufacturer or other authorised 3rd party
         for repair, as defined for each Equipment type in the appendices.
2.13.3   All designs shall provide high reliability and the Mean Time Between Failure
         (MTBF) and the resulting availability figures shall be calculated in
         accordance with the PD IEC TR 62380.
2.13.4   MTBF/ availability may be competitively compared in supply tenders where
         higher availability may offer an advantage:
                Minimum MTBF requirements, Equipment 'Working Phases' and
                 repair access assumptions may be defined within Highways England
                 tender documentation.

2.13.5   Where optical designs use 'colour mixing' techniques to achieve colour class
         requirements, the 'colour mixes' shall be reconfigurable as described in
         TR2608 to ensure that compliance with the required colour classes can be
         maintained over the life of the product in the event of uneven colour
         degradation.
2.13.6   Maintenance (including any periodic testing and calibration) proposals shall
         be submitted as part of the Technical File and Highways England's cost for
         undertaking maintenance, including cost of deploying plant and traffic
         management, will be competitively compared as part of the whole life cost of
         ownership during the tender assessment process.
                Maintenance proposals shall include the frequency of visits and the
                 time spent on site for each routine maintenance task
                Routine maintenance visits that coincide with Highways England's 6-
                 yearly electrical inspections will attract the least whole-life cost
                 during the tender assessment process.

         to prevent maintenance personnel having to work at height unnecessarily,

         reprogrammed with software updates from the roadside cabinet.

2.14     Construction - General
2.14.1   Display Equipment dimensions, optical design and display areas are defined
         for each Display Equipment type in the appendices.
2.14.2   Display Equipment shall provide a display which is free from reflections from
         likely external light sources (e.g. vehicle headlamps; street lighting).
2.14.3   Display Equipment shall maintain its optical performance characteristics to
         the stated BS EN 12966 performance classes over the expected 15 year
         operational life, based on an anticipated minimum overall daily 33% duty
         cycle.
2.14.4   To allow interchangeability with Equipment from various suppliers, Display
         Equipment, including any mounting brackets supplied, shall be compatible
         with the standard structural interface details as shown in the appendices:
         these assume the optical axis will be perpendicular to the front face.
2.14.5   The enclosure and its fixing arrangements shall allow for tolerance in
         member sizes due to fabrication and the differential expansion effects of the
         enclosure and support structure.
2.14.6   The arrangement shall ensure that the loads are applied to the mounting
         points on the supporting structure in proportion to their spacing using a
         sufficient number of fixings, such that there is sufficient capacity to support
         the sign equipment, whilst there is an associated failure of at least 50% of
         the proposed fixings, in whatever configuration provides the worst case
         loading scenario. The capacity of the remaining fixings shall also consider
         the capacity of the supporting framework elements, such that the remaining
         supporting elements and their connections are no over loaded in the above
         worse case configuration.
            Note: The above is intended to provide structural 'redundancy' such that
            the enclosure remains safely attached to the supporting structure, but not
            necessarily operational, in the event of a significant failure of the
            proposed fixings. This does not preclude the use of additional fixings or
            tethers to achieve this
2.14.7   To facilitate installation/ removal by 3rd parties, Display Equipment
         Enclosures shall incorporate permanent lifting points as shown in the
         appendices for each Display Equipment type.
2.14.8   Installation earthing methods for all Equipment shall comply with BS 7671 -
         ‘Requirements for Electrical Installation IEE Wiring Regulations’ and BS
         7430 - ‘Code of Practice for Earthing’.
2.14.9   Wiring between modules or within an enclosure shall comply with BS EN
         60445.
2.14.10 All lightning Surge Arrestors fitted should be installed as close as possible to
        the point of cable entry to Equipment enclosures.
2.14.11 To facilitate safe and efficient maintenance. for items defined as 'maintained
        in situ',

2.14.14 Ambient Light Monitors or Light Sensor Unit (where they are integral to

                Be calibrated to cover the full range of light levels from bright
                 sunlight to darkness

2.15     Construction - Display Equipment Enclosures
2.15.1   Enclosures shall comply with class WL8 in BS EN 12899-1.
           Note: This performance class is stated so that standard Equipment is
           suitable at the majority of locations in England. However, where local
           specific wind conditions prove to be greater than the loads imposed by
           WL8, a higher performance class may be specified in tender
           documentation. It is the responsibility of the Scheme Designer to ensure
           that before Equipment supplied in accordance with this specification is
           installed, it is suitable for the intended location
2.15.2   The deflection class for the enclosures due to temporary loads shall be
         TDB1 in accordance with BS EN 12899-1.
2.15.3   The deflection class for the enclosures due to dynamic snow loads shall be
         DSL4 in accordance with BS EN 12899-1.




TR2607 Issue A                        Page 16 of 90

2.15.4   All other loads and combinations for the enclosures shall be calculated in
         accordance with BS EN 12966.
2.15.5   Wind force and pressure coefficients shall be calculated in accordance with
         BS EN 1991-1-4, Eurocode 1: Actions on Structures – Part 1-4: General
         Actions – Wind Actions.
2.15.6   Deformations in the serviceability limit state shall be limited such that they
         do not exceed the values given in BD51/14 Table 4.1 for the Characteristic
         combination of actions.
2.15.7   Enclosures may be manufactured from any material that will meet the
         performance requirements of this specification over the design life of the
         Equipment. Consideration should be given to reducing the effects of solar
         gain to minimise the effects of internal temperature rise.
2.15.8   Enclosures manufactured from aluminium or steel shall comply with BS EN
         1090: Execution of steel structures and aluminium structures .
2.15.9   Front facing surfaces shall be Matt Black. Where Side and Rear facing
         surfaces are painted to achieve the required design life and/or reduce solar
         gain, these may be Grey 18B21 BS4800 (non-reflective) for consistency of
         appearance with other installed equipment. Unpainted surfaces shall be
         dulled. All finishes shall give a high quality aesthetic appearance and retain
         their colour and consistency of finish for the design life of the Equipment.

                 IEEE 802.3-2012 clause 28 and clause 40 (802.3z/802.3ab).
                100M/1000M short haul single mode duplex optical Ethernet
                 transceiver of type LX complying with standard IEEE 802.3-2012
                 clause 38
                100M/1000M short haul single mode bi-directional optical Ethernet
                 transceiver of type BX complying with standard IEEE 802.3-2012
                 clause 59 with transmit and receive wavelengths of 1310nm and
                 1490nm respectively.

shall be verified with each, prior to Equipment delivery
B5     Where an auto-negotiate function for Ethernet or Fibre interfaces is provided, it

compatible with any other 3rd party provided SFP transceiver that fully complies with
the Small Form-factor Pluggable (SFP) Multisource agreement (INF-8074i Rev 1.0).
B7    Dust/EMI cover plug shall be inserted into empty cage assembly bays.

APPENDIX D REQUIREMENTS FOR AMI

General
D1      AMI Signals used to present traffic control centre-governed displays to the road
will:
                 Be installed directly on to new gantry infrastructure, which will be
                  provided by others and, at some locations, may include provisions
                  for manned access to the rear of the AMIs
                 Replace legacy (Version 2 and earlier) AMIs installed on existing
                  infrastructure which generally will not include provisions for manned
                  access
                 For installations where rear manned access is provided, the AMI
                  shall be capable of being fully maintained and repaired safely whilst
                  remaining installed on its mounting structure, without the need for
                  lane closures
                 For installations where rear manned access is not provided:
                     o The AMI shall be capable of being safely removed from the
                       structure and replaced with a working unit within a period of
                       30 minutes, for subsequent repair off-site, OR
                     o Be capable of being safely maintained and repaired safely
                       from a MEWP within a period of 30 minutes.
D2      This appendix sets out the requirements for functionally compliant and
infrastructure-compatible AMIs.


Function
D3      AMIs are required to display Aspects (together with/without a steady-
illuminated Red Ring and/or flashing Lanterns) as required by TR2608.


Optical Design
D4     The AMI Aspect Display Area shall have a display resolution to comply with the
Aspect formats prescribed TR2608. The arrangements shown assume a 32x32
matrix with a nominal 20mm display cell pitch but compliant alternatives will not be
precluded.
D5   The Aspect Display Area and 'Red Ring' shall meet the performance classes of
BS EN 12966 as stated in section 2 for colours:
                 White
                 Red.

Section 4 System Description And Performance
Requirements


4.1.     Introduction


4.1.1.   This Section defines the principal business, customer service, operational and
         particular performance requirements of the train.


4.1.2.   The train shall provide commuter and leisure journeys for the widest possible
         range of demographic types of the CITY population including the disabled in
         line with the AUTHORITY's Policy.


4.1.3.   The train shall be interchangeable train to train with the existing T1 Trains.


4.1.4.   The train must be capable of being operated to provide the specified passenger
         service in conjunction with the presence of the T1 Trains in accordance with
         the existing Time Tables.




4.2.     Business Requirements


4.2.1.   The exterior livery and interior of the train shall deliver an image of high
         quality and promote the status of the AUTHORITY as the premium transport
         service in CITY. Whilst the overall design requirements are defined
         herein the Contractor shall meet the design requirements to achieve the
         visual design as specified in PS 6 and 7.


4.2.2.   The train shall produce a modern, comfortable, cheerful interior conveying an
         impression of speed, efficiency, and safety while maintaining a strong
         AUTHORITY’s image of care for passengers.

4.2.3.   The train shall be designed and constructed for operational safety both under
         normal operating and maintenance conditions and in the event of equipment
         failure.


4.2.4.   The features of the trains including the train consist arrangement shall be
         optimised to maximise the performance and minimise the energy consumption
         cost, train operation and maintenance cost.

4.3.       Customer Service Requirements


4.3.1.     Speed
           A commercial speed of not less than 33 km/h (20.6 MPH) shall be achieved in
           a condition of a minimum of 5% coasting including 15 seconds of station
           dwell time and fully laden load (refer to PS 4.5.3) on all Existing Subway
           Lines and new extension.


4.3.2.     Saloon Environment
    (a)    The train environment shall be comfortable with air-conditioning and
           adequate ventilation (refer to PS 15).


    (b)    An adequate lighting level shall be provided (refer to PS 7).


    (c)    The train interior space shall be optimised and the free floor area in the saloon
           shall be maximised.


    ( d ) The capacity requirements are specified in PS 7.4.


    ( e ) A wide gangway shall be provided to connect the saloons of adjacent cars,
          providing a maximum clear view through the train and capacity for standing
          passengers and for effective evacuation during an emergency. Detailed
          requirements are specified in PS 14.


4.3.3.     Train Reliability


    (a)    The train shall achieve the reliability requirement as specified in PS 25.7.



    (b)    The train shall achieve the availability requirement as specified in PS 25.8.
4.3.4.     Passenger Information
           Signage shall be easily understood by passengers with effective and
           coordinated use of graphic and text. All signs shall be in English. Detailed
           requirements are specified in PS 7.15.

4.3.5.   A public address system shall be provided using high quality recording and
         digitisation in English for routine announcements. Detailed requirements are
         specified in PS 18.


4.3.6.   Passenger assistance alarm facilities with clear instructions shall be provided
         in the compartments for passengers to gain the attention of the train operator
         and establish a two-way voice communication in emergency situations.

4.3.7.   On-board passenger information displays shall be provided. Detailed

5.1       Kinematic Envelope
          The Contractor shall submit for approval, by using well accepted computer
          modelling techniques, such as VAMPIRE®, to provide a calculated
          Kinematic Envelope (also known as the Maximum Moving Dimension) of the
          vehicle in order to demonstrate the vehicle compatibility with the
          infrastructure and ensure that the maximum dynamic displacement of a
          vehicle outline from track centre-line and from rail level shall not exceed the
          gauge lines as detailed on the Contract Drawings No. NST 003 to 005 under
          the conditions specified in PS 5.2. Unless otherwise specified, a minimum
          clearance of 100mm (3.94”) shall be provided between the kinematic
          envelope and the undercar equipment gauge line (refer to Contract Drawing
          No. NST 004).

8.4        Train Operator Duties


8.4.1.     Job Purpose


           The train operator is responsible for passenger train safety and the efficient
           operation of the trains (both on running lines and in Yards and sidings) in
           accordance with the working timetables or special schedule. The train

Section 8, page 8-8


          operator executes the duties in compliance with the relevant Commission's
          manuals or documents.


8.4.2.    Main Train Operator Tasks


    (a)   Train preparation - As detailed in PS 9.2.


    (b)   Manual operation - As detailed in PS 9.6


    (c)   Saloon door opening and closing at platforms using controls provided on the
          Train Operator Console. The guard shall also be required to operate these door
          opening and closing controls, whilst standing at the corresponding cab side.


    (d)   Communication with the passengers, Traffic Controller in the Transit Control
          Centre, Yard Controller and train operator.


    (e)   Safety monitoring, defects and incidents handling, and co-ordination of safety
          procedures and actions.


    (f)   Observation of track signals as described in PS 8.5.


    (g)   Observation of Platform Mirror allowing the train operator a full view of the
          platform and train doors from the seated position.


    (h)   Vision and shunting within the Yard environment.


    (i)   Observation and control during train coupling and uncoupling.


  8.4.3   Functional Responsibilities


    (a)   Equipment Operating Skills

The train operator is required to operate the Controller Handle, switches and
      equipment (such as TIMS, Radio, DVAS and PA) installed in the driving cab.
      The required operating skills and the associated training requirements shall be
      kept to a minimum.


(b)   Decision Making


      Based on job knowledge, the train operator must make quick and logical
      decisions to handle train defects or to deal with emergency incidents, without
      referring to supervisor.


(c)   Fault Detection and Reporting


      With the aid of the TIMS, the train operator shall be able to diagnose fault
      symptoms, identify train defect(s) and initiate appropriate actions to recover

Section 8, page 8-9


          train service, independently or with the assistance from other staff, if
          necessary but the design shall minimise the operating tasks.


    (d)   Supervision/Management


          Through the communication system of the train (refer to PS 18), the train
          operator shall be able to obtain direct supervision from the train staff
          supervisor. During the handling of train defect or dealing with an incident, the
          train operator communicates or consults when required with Traffic Controller
          in the Transit Control Centre or the Station Local In-charge.



8.5       Vision Requirements


8.5.1.    General


    (a)   The cab design shall maximise the train operator's vision through the cab
          windscreens and the cab side windows.


    (b)   The vision requirements shall be met by both seated and standing train
          operators.


    (c)   Sight lines shall not be distorted by glass as required by PS 6.11.


    (d)   Reflections from indicators, displays and console wash lighting shall not
          adversely affect the train operator's vision by day or by night.


    (e)   The colour of the glass on the cab side windows shall not affect the perception
          of signals, platform mirrors or any other exterior displays, as required by PS
          6.11.


8.5.2.    Signal Sight Lines


    (a)   Signals will be positioned to the side of the track within a height range of

track level to a maximum height of 3.5 m (12’).


(b)   Signals will be positioned predominantly to the right hand side of the track, at
      a distance of no more than 750 mm (30”) outside the structure gauge.


(c)   The train operator, without head or body movement, shall have full sight of all
      signals down to a distance of 4 m (13’) or less, measured between the front of
      the train and the signal.


(d)   Under the permission of TCC, the train operator can manually key-by an
      automatic signal that has a red aspect lit. Typically, the key-by levers are
      located approximately ten feet ahead of the signal. To ensure the compatibility

Section 8, page 8-10


          with this key-by operation, it is a requirement that the distance between the
          centre lines of the cab window and the first leading truck shall be similar to
          the T1 train distance. The Contractor shall demonstrate that the manual key-by
          operation can be done by a train operator in the NST design.


    (e)   When the above key-by operation is completed, it is a requirement that the
          train operator shall be able to visually check the wayside train stop arm has
          cleared.


8.5.3.    Vision of the Train Operator Console


          The train operator shall have a full view of all displays and controls in the cab
          in both the seated and the standing positions.

8.16.3.      Mechanism


   (a)       The detrainment door mechanism shall be robust and durable. Its fitness for
             purpose shall be proven by type test as stipulated in Appendix B Clause 2.11.


   (b)       The mechanism shall be designed to prevent rattling, chafing or mechanical
             degradation in any way during its service life in the stowed position.


   (c)       When operated, the mechanism shall function in a safe and secure manner that
             inspires confidence in use of the device amongst potentially disoriented users.
             Loud noises shall be avoided during deployment.


   (d)       The deployment rate shall be controlled to minimise risk of injury to users or
             other third parties in front of the train. It shall allow sufficient time for an able
             bodied person to move out of the way if an unexpected release of the ramp
             occurs.


   (e)       For the automatic deployment of the secondary ramp, its rate of deployment
             shall be carefully designed to reduce the risk of passenger injury in an attempt
             to rush out into the ramp.


   (f)       The mechanism shall be designed to be safe for use by untrained users
             presenting no finger traps or other dangers when deployed.


   (g)       The walking surface of the deployed detrainment ramp shall be:


   ( i )     stiff
   ( i i )     clear and flat
   ( i i i )     anti-slip, even when wet

( i ) The edges of the ramp shall be clearly marked.

       assist the detrainment of passengers.


( k ) An emergency hand held flashlight shall be attached on the panel adjacent to
      the detrainment door panel.

   ( i i i )    all environmental conditions as specified.

         member of the public in less than 1 minute (refer to 8.16.2(c)). The
         satisfactory achievement of this shall be determined by type test using
         untrained persons in a simulated emergency situation.


   ( d ) The method of deployment shall be designed to safeguard against the
         possibility of accidental deployment. Deployment shall require a specific and
         deliberate act.

          posed to the Railway, if the level of the water/mud does reach above the rail
          foot but below the rail top, the train shall be able to operate under
          Forward/Reverse mode to a maximum speed of 25 km/h (15 MPH) in order to
          maintain a minimum degree of train service under a flooding condition.

          1475-1999 “IEEE Standard for the Functioning of and Interfaces among

10.1.2.   The design of the TIMS shall consider the train as a total complete system and
          the TIMS shall provide a centralized function to control and monitor all its
          subsystems operation and fault status, fault data logging, incident
          investigation and reporting.


10.1.3.   The TIMS shall provide for real-time distributed control and modular
          processing of subsystems in a redundant manner with high reliability and
          availability in the adverse operating environment.


10.1.4.   The TIMS shall be designed for ease of fault diagnosis and maintenance.


10.1.5.   The TIMS shall function as an Event Recorder to record operating status of
          critical control circuits and components.


10.1.6.   The TIMS shall be designed to minimize the needs for individual trainline
          wires and hardwires across couplers. The type of TIMS transmission link to
          be used shall preferably be a screened coaxial cable but a fiber optic cable
          may also be proposed as an alternative. These proposed links shall be proven
          in a comparable operating environment.


10.1.7.   The TIMS system and architecture will be developed in order to meet the

overall RAMS trainset requirement.

10.2.1.   Train Information Network (TIN)


   (a)    The TIN shall be based on a two-level hierarchy structure consisting of a
          Train Consist Network and System Sub-Network(s). System Sub-Network
          shall be connected to the Train Consist Network via a System Sub-Network
          Gateway. Communications protocols shall be complied with or derived from
          the IEEE Std 1473-1999 “IEEE Standard for Communications Protocol

        Aboard Trains”.


(b)     TIN Initialization


(i)     The TIN initialization shall be started once the power up initialization of the
        train has occurred. No train operator intervention is required during the
        initialization process.


(ii)    The TIN shall first check the healthy status of all the TIN equipment including
        Train Consist Network, System Sub-Networks, ATC / Communications
        Gateways, Gateways, LPU's with real time clock, TIMS display terminal,
        Event Recorder and Control Interface Units. All equipment failures shall be
        logged, displayed on the TIMS display terminal and reported to the YMSS if
        train is within the coverage of the YMSS.


(iii)   The TIN shall then configure itself automatically. Each connected device shall
        receive a unique address identifying its position and orientation (left/right,
        front/rear).


( i v ) Once the initialization process is completed, data communication service shall
        be started and data shall be able to be transferred among any connected
        devices.


( v ) Default operating and control parameters / values (including the recording
       schemes of the Event Recorder) shall be transmitted to each train subsystems.
       These default operating parameters / values shall be able to be viewed, edited
       and changed by maintenance staff when the TIMS is in the Maintenance
       Mode. The default operating and control parameters / values shall set all train
       subsystems / devices in the safe state (for example brakes to be applied and
       doors closed). Operating Parameters shall be modifiable using the Portable PC
       and/or the YMSS computer.


( v i ) The train consist shall be uncoupled / coupled on major maintenance activity
        by maintenance staff. The TIN shall be able to maintain partial operation of
        both the Train Consist Network and System sub-network(s) on all uncoupled
        units. This may be achieved by automatic or manual operation of switches,
        insertion of matching resistors or other methods. Once uncoupling / coupling

is completed, the TIN shall re-configure itself automatically to enable the data
       communication service unless the cars forming the consist have changed. In
       this eventuality, the consist shall be reconfigured using a portable PC. The
       train consist as recognised by the TIMS shall be displayed on the TIMS
       display terminal.


( v i i ) From power up initialization of the train, the TIN of TIMS shall complete its

(i)   Train Service Regulation Requirement


      The design of the PIS shall facilitate the following train service regulation and
      display the correct information as soon as new data are received from the
      TIMS.

Section 10, page 10-29



(1)   Change of line during service


      The train may change line during the service run. The PIS shall be able to
      display the correct destination according to the change of the route code.


(2)   Turn short at station


      The train may be turned short at some stations. The PIS shall be able to
      display the destination according to the change of the destination code.


(3)   Time out protection


      The time out protection shall be provided such that when no signal is received
      from the DiCU for 10 minutes, the display panels LEDs shall be switched off
      in order not to show any incorrect information to the passengers. Upon receipt
      of valid signal from the DiCU, the display panels LEDs shall be switched on
      again and response according to the signal command.


      The time out protection shall be provided such that when no signal is received
      from the DiCU for three consecutive heartbeat (TIMS Global Data refreshed
      at +/- 100 msec), the display panels LEDs shall revert to default display in
      order not to show any incorrect information to the passengers. Upon receipt of
      valid signal from the DiCU, the display panels LEDs shall be switched on
      again and response according to the signal command.




(j)   Interface with DiCU


      The PIS shall obtain the following information from DiCU:


(1)   Route Code


      Route code contains the information of the line and direction in which the

train is running. The route code shall include the 8 normal service line
      numbers and the special line numbers due to train service regulation.


(2)   Station Code


      Station code contains the information of the next station the train shall arrive.
      A new station code shall be received from the TIMS when the train leave the

10.3.2.   Automatic System Initialization

(a)   When the train systems are initialized (refer to PS 9.2), the TIMS shall
      automatically perform initial checking of all TIMS sub-systems. It shall then
      initiate static function and sequence testing for all trainborne systems to verify
      correct functions and healthiness. Should no system malfunction be detected,
      the TIMS shall transmit a "train healthy" signal back to both the YMSS when
      the train is located inside the depot, and the train operator. Otherwise,
      respective fault code and diagnostic messages shall be transmitted to the
      YMSS.
      In addition, an extended concept of "Train Birth Certficate" involving a
      complete Train Systems Test under TIMS supervision shall be provided. The
      birth certificate shall comprise two components:

Section 10, page 10-37


   (i)    An interactive pre-departure test sequence commanded by the Subway Yard
            Operator (SYO) to test on-board systems and validate that they meet their
            respective operability requirements;
   (ii) A manual verification performed by the SYO.
            The result of the pre-departure tests shall be kept internally in the TIMS and
            sent to the YMSS. The YMSS shall allow printing of pre-departure test
            reports, including the manual verification checklist. A successfull pre-
            departure test shall be valid only for a limited period of time (8 hours), after
            which it shall fall back to "Required" status. The pre-departure test status shall

         completed and data communication service is available. The 600VDC third

10.3.6.   Defect Handling


          Based on the capability of the individual train systems and the associated
          failure effect, faults detected shall be handled by the following three modes:


   (a)    Automatic defect handling

(i)    When a train system is reported faulty, it shall report to the TIMS and
       automatically attempt to re-start.


(ii)   For those system/equipment failure which significantly affect normal
       passenger service shall be managed automatically through the TIMS and
       displayed             to             the              train             operator.
       In addition, the TIMS will derive from the correspondance of Events to
       Register of Train Failure (RTF) criteria, a train healthiness status that will be

Section 10, page 10-41


          provided to the YMSS as specified in 18.6.6 (d) herein.




   (b)    Semi-automatic defect handling


   (i)    When a train system is reported faulty, it shall report to the TIMS and advise
          the train operator to re-start it through the TIMS display terminal.


   (ii)   For that system/equipment failure which requires operation decision to be
          made by the train operator shall be managed semi-automatically through the
          TIMS and displayed to the train operator.


   (c)    Manual defect handling


   (i)    When a train system is reported faulty, it shall report to the TIMS and advise
          the train operator how to re-start it remotely from the driving cab and/or
          locally in the concerned car.


   (ii)   For that system/equipment failure which requires operation intervention to be
          made by the train operator shall be managed manually and displayed to the
          train operator.


          In order to reduce the time for fault recovery, due consideration shall be given
          to ensure full automatic defect handling functions are provided as far as
          practicable.

10.4.6.      Data Management


   (a)       The TIN shall cater for the following two different types of data:


   (i)       Process data which consist of frequent, time-critical but short duration data
             (for example traction control data)


   (ii)      Message data which consist of less urgent but possibly lengthy data (for
             example logging)


   (b)       The TIN shall support the transmission of the two types of data by offering the
             following data transmission service:


   ( i )     Periodic data transmission which transmits data at a regular interval


   ( i i )     Sporadic data transmission which transmits data on request or when
             triggered by an event


   (c)       Periodic Data Transmission


   ( i )     Periodic data transmission service shall occupy a small portion of the basic
             network activity period. During this period, process data which are critical
             shall be transmitted.


   ( i i )    The transmission shall be processed without a check back to avoid delay
   in
             receiving acknowledgement from receivers.


   (iii)     Freshness supervision shall be employed to avoid operating with obsolete data

as a result of equipment failure.


(iv)   Error recovery is inherent due to the cyclic transmission of data. A lost sample
       shall be refreshed in next transmission. The safety of transmission shall be
       guaranteed by this cyclic transmission and the cyclic redundancy check sum
       associated with each package of process data.


(d)    Sporadic Data Transmission


(i)    Sporadic data transmission service shall occupy the remaining portion of the
       basic network activity period. It shall transmit message data, if there is any,
       which is less urgent.

Section 10, page 10-53


(ii)      The transmission shall be processed with check back by the receiving unit to
          ensure a reliable transmission.


(iii)     In the event that the sporadic data transmission service is used for transmitting
          safety related control signals (refer to PS 9.9), a higher priority shall be
          assigned which ensures that they are transmitted in advance of other lower
          priority data.


(e)       The Contractor shall submit calculations and quantitative analysis for
          approval to demonstrate that the allocation of periodic and sporadic data
          transmission is appropriate in delivering the required performance.

Section 11           Traction And Braking Equipment


11.1      General


11.1.1.   The traction and braking system proposed shall be of proven design suitable
          for the specified performance levels. The design of the power converter shall
          comply with IEC 61287-1:1995 and shall be tested to IEC 61377:1996 and
          IEC 61377-3:2002.


11.1.2.   An AC traction motor system shall be utilised. The AC traction motors and
          associated drive system proposed shall be designed to perform all normal and
          emergency duties as specified in PS 4, without damage or deterioration to the
          motors or their associated connections which may lead to subsequent
          premature failure.


11.1.3.   The traction and braking system shall meet performance under all conditions
          of wheel wear including up to 6mm (0.25”) of wheel diameter mismatch on
          axles in the same truck.


11.1.4.   The system shall be designed for optimum performance in terms of reliability
          and maintainability and with minimum energy consumption.


11.1.5.   The specific energy consumption shall be guaranteed and verified during the
          testing stage. Requirements for the verification and validation of the energy
          consumption shall be as specified in Appendix C.


11.2      System Configuration
          The traction and braking equipment shall have the following characteristics:


11.2.1.   Two truck frame mounted 3-phase AC induction motors per motored truck.


11.2.2.   A 3-phase self-ventilated traction converter control system with dynamic
          braking (both regenerative and rheostatic) capability, each powering the two

parallel connected motors of one motored truck. All traction converters shall
          be identical, interchangeable and underframe mounted.


11.2.3.   Separate and independent slip/slide control for each truck and detection for
          each axle.


11.2.4.   Separate friction brake interface and brake blending control for each truck.


11.2.5.   An energise-to-release, fail-safe, pneumatic friction emergency braking
          system.

Section 11, page 11-3


11.2.6.         The electro-pneumatic service and emergency brakes shall operate the same
                brake actuators.


11.2.7.         An automatic spring-applied, air-released parking brake.


11.3            Control Interface
11.3.1.         The modes of operation shall be as defined in PS 9.5. No change of travelling
                direction shall be allowed unless the train speed is less than 1 km/h (0.62
                MPH).


11.3.2.         A screened twist pairs train line shall be provided to transmit the tractive
                effort/braking effort demand in the form of pulse width modulation to the
                traction and braking equipment. The signal transmission of the above tractive
                effort/braking effort demand shall be independent with the TIMS operation.


11.3.3.         The above demand shall be generated in the form of a pulse width which shall
                be modulated by the traction brake controller. The circuit shall be designed in
                a manner that the PWM signal of the tractive effort/braking effort command
                shall only be available from the traction brake controller of the selected
                driving cab


11.3.4.         The demand level received by all the traction and braking equipment on the
                train shall be identical.


11.3.5.         The tractive effort/braking effort output from the traction and braking
                equipment shall be according to the demand level received from the traction
                brake controller and within the normal working range of the control signal as

11.4      Mode of Operation
11.4.1.   The traction equipment shall be capable of operation in various modes
          according to PS 9.5. The traction equipment shall respond to the traction brake
          controller handle positions. The characteristics of the tractive effort/braking
          effort output versus the traction brake controller position shall be referred to
          PS 9.6.


11.5      Power Contactors Control
          For safety purpose, the following arrangements for initiating the traction or
          braking circuit shall be provided:


11.5.1.   The initial setting-up of the traction circuit for motoring or dynamic braking
          shall be controlled in all cases by two separate train lines.


11.5.2.   Whenever zero tractive or braking effort is demanded, the current in the
          traction motors shall be ramped to zero under jerk rate control and if
          necessary the power contactors shall open after a time delay .


          Whenever zero tractive or braking effort is demanded, the tractive effort in the
          traction motors shall be ramped to zero under jerk rate control.


11.5.3.   The time delay shall be provided to prevent the switching of the power
          contactors in the event of changing mode of operation from motoring to
          braking                     and               vice               versa.
          Changing mode of operation from motoring to braking and vice versa should
          not require operation of the power contactor.


11.5.4.   De-energising either of the appropriate two master train lines for a duration
          longer than the time delay shall cause the traction equipment to be
          disconnected                   from               the                supply.
          De-energising either of the appropriate two master train lines shall cause the
          traction equipment to be disconnected from the supply.


11.5.5.   A stray feed onto any one control wire, not necessarily a train line, shall not

prevent the traction equipment from being disconnected from the supply.


11.5.6.   To avoid any contact tip wear due to arcing, the motor current shall be ramped
          to zero before the power contactors open under normal conditions.


11.5.7.   Any of the following events shall cause the traction converter to switch off
          immediately without jerk limit control and the power contactors to open
          immediately:


   (a)    emergency brake is demanded;

   (b)
           motoring or braking circuit overload

11.8      Dynamic Braking Requirements
11.8.1.   The dynamic brake shall be continuously available from 85km/h (53 MPH)
          down to 5 km/h (3 MPH) or less for the purpose of minimising the brake pad
          or block wear and maximising the regeneration of energy within the limits of
          adhesion.


11.8.2.   The dynamic braking shall consist of regenerative and rheostatic braking,
          which shall complement each other, depending on the third rail receptivity and
          braking priorities as specified below:


   (a)    Under normal circumstances, regenerative braking shall have the first priority
          in the braking process and provide the full braking effort requested. In order to

Section 11, page 11-18


          optimise the size of the traction motor and inverter, a dynamic brake taper
          above 45 KPH is permitted.


   ( b ) In case the line voltage transiently increases up to 720VDC, regenerative
         braking shall be transferred to rheostatic braking without noticeable change of
         brake effort, i.e. the blending of regenerative and rheostatic brake shall be
         smooth, continuous and reversible. The rheostatic braking resistor shall have
         transient thermal capacity to absorb all of the dynamic brake energy, for one
         station stop with W4 passenger loads from maximum speed. This will ensure
         smooth braking transition from the above transient over-voltage conditions.
         However, the thermal capacity of the rheostatic brake resistor shall assume
         continuous 50% line receptivity, followed by a worst case station stop with
         0% line receptivity, without exceeding 650 ºC. The regenerative and
         rheostatic brakes transferring process shall be continuously reversible
         provided the temperature limit of the braking resistor is not exceeded. Control
         software shall predict the temperature of the rheostatic brake resistors and
         transition smoothly to friction braking at 600 ºC. Once temperature
         predictions fall to safe levels, dynamic braking shall be maximized.


   ( c ) If the third rail system is totally receptive , dynamic braking shall be rated at a
          line voltage of 660 VDC minimum.


   ( d ) Should the third rail system continue to be either partially or totally
         non-receptive, dynamic braking shall still be maximised by a smooth
         transition of regenerative/friction brake blending or revert totally to pneumatic
         service brake respectively without loss of brake effort until the receptivity of
         the third rail system is resumed. The short term braking resistor may be used
         to ensure smooth braking transition from receptive to non receptive conditions
         and vice versa.


   ( e ) When there is no dynamic brake available, the total required brake force shall
         be provided by the friction brake.


   ( f ) Any increase in receptivity during blended brake application shall result in a
         reduction in the level of friction or rheostatic braking and a resultant increase
         in the regenerated energy. For detailed requirements of brake blending shall
         refer to PS 11.12.


11.8.3.   The motor unit associated with the trailer car shall provide the dynamic brake

for the combination of motor and trailer cars such that the regeneration is
          maximised and the wear of the friction brake equipment is minimised.


11.8.4.   The braking effort shall be regulated among the combination of motor and
          trailer cars such that the maximum use of the available adhesion is achieved in
          meeting the demanded braking effort.


11.8.5.   Due consideration shall be given to avoid excessive stress build up in the

Section 11, page 11-19


          mechanical structure particularly the coupler between the trailer and motor
          cars caused by the above combination of braking efforts.


11.8.6.   Response times during brake blending shall be minimised to facilitate a
          smooth and non jerky operation.


11.8.7.   Within the jerk limits specified, the electric brake shall be built up as rapidly
          as possible to maximise regeneration and minimise wear of the friction brake.


11.8.8.   The regenerative braking shall not cause the line voltage to exceed 720VDC.


11.8.9.   The Contractor shall submit for approval a system study indicating the effect

          shall confirm that the regenerative brake shall not cause the fault rupturing
          capacity of the protective equipment of the cars to be exceeded.


11.9      Friction Brake
11.9.1.   The friction braking shall be achieved by means of a friction brake and shall
          be rated to meet the specified braking performance without assistance from
          the electrical brake.


11.9.2.   The Contractor shall demonstrate by theoretical study, such as, finite element
          analysis, that the thermal stress built up on the wheel and braking equipment,
          for example, the brake pad or block, due to frequent friction braking operation
          according to the conditions specified in PS 11.9.3 below shall not exceed the
          recommended values given by the suppliers.


11.9.3.   The friction brake block shall be capable of a series of 3 consecutive
          emergency brake applications from maximum speed down to standstill on a
          crush laden vehicle. The vehicle shall accelerate at its maximum rate up to
          maximum speed after each stop then immediately undergo an emergency
          brake application down to a standstill whereupon the train shall be
          immediately restarted. This shall not cause the wheel any damage and block
          material to change its friction or wear characteristics and shall not cause
          excessive wear of the friction material.

11.11      Combined Brake Control Principles
11.11.1.   The combined braking between the dynamic and friction brake shall be

11.12      Brake Blending
11.12.1.   Dynamic braking and friction braking shall be continuously blended to
           provide the required deceleration rates defined in PS 11.14.


11.12.2.   Throughout dynamic braking process, the friction brake shall be such that the
           brake block is just touching the wheel tread or disc for the purpose of
           improving the adhesion between the wheel tread and rail and reducing the
           brake response time.


11.12.3.   The dynamic braking shall be preferential and the friction braking shall be
           applied only under the conditions specified in PS 11.8.2.


11.12.4.   The blending control between dynamic brake and friction brakes shall be
           continuously reversible and carried out automatically.


11.12.5.   The blending control between dynamic and friction braking shall not cause
           any loss of braking effort.


11.12.6.   Prior to the final stop, the brake control system shall provide a brake fade out
           function to facilitate a smooth and non jerky stop. Friction brake blending
           control during dynamic brake fade, shall ensure no more than a ±5% change
           of total braking effort relative to the demanded braking effort.


11.12.7.   The brake blending at some lower speed when the electric brake fades out

shall be smooth.


11.12.8.   Fade shall occur at the lowest practical speed applicable to the above
           requirement. The speed at which electric brake fade occurs shall not be more
           than 10 km/h.


11.12.9.   The Contractor shall ensure that effective wheel slide protection is adequately
           provided throughout the brake blending process.


11.12.10. If wheel slide is detected then electric brake effort shall be smoothly ramped
           down and smoothly reapplied as soon as wheel slide has been corrected. At
           the same time, the friction brake shall also be suitably controlled to prevent

11.13      Wheel Slip and Slide Protection
11.13.1.   A wheel slip/slide protection system shall be provided to minimise damage to
           the wheel sets and prevent damage to the traction motors/transmissions during
           wheel slip or slide. The following definitions shall be applied to the design of
           the wheel slip/slide protection system:


   (a)     At a coefficient of adhesion of 0.07 or greater, the efficiency of the wheel slip
           and slide protection system shall be at least 75 percent in acceleration and
           braking over the speed range between maximum speed and 10 km/h.


   (b)     The wheel slide efficiency shall be defined as the ratio of the actual braking
           rate to the theoretical braking rate from an initial brake entry speed to a lower
           speed.


   (c)     The wheel spin efficiency shall be defined as the ratio of the actual
           accelerating rate to the theoretical accelerating rate, from an initial speed to a
           higher speed.


   (d)     The theoretical rate is that which is obtained by continuously utilizing the
           available track (wheel-to-rail) adhesion.


   (e)     Efficiency shall be calculated over the slip-affected portions of operation.


11.13.2.   The wheel slip/slide protection, if not an integral part of the traction and
           braking equipment, shall provide the signals, for example the slide signal,
           needed by the traction equipment and other systems.

12.11      Air Suspension
12.11.1.   The truck shall be fitted with air suspension which shall maintain a constant
           floor height in the car under all conditions of loading (excluding primary
           suspension deflection).


12.11.2.   In the event of a fault resulting in over inflation or deflation of the airsprings,
           the car shall be able to operate safely at its normal operating speeds. Under
           these conditions the truck acceleration levels shall not exceed 0.4g RMS for 2
           seconds when measured in accordance with 49 CFR 213.333 prescriptions.
           Also the weighted journey average ride both in the vertical and lateral
           directions shall not be worse than the existing T-1 Cars. This shall be achieved
           without the use of extra features, e.g. dampers, which would not be required to
           achieve the ride requirements in the normally inflated condition.


12.12      Pipework and Hoses
12.12.1.   Brake-pipes, hoses and conduits shall be installed such that risk of damage
           such as from flying ballast is minimised.


12.12.2.   Brake-pipes and conduits shall be supported with suitable cleats at intervals of
           not greater than 300 mm (12”). Cleats shall be positioned so as to avoid high
           stressed areas of the truck frame.


12.12.3.   It shall be physically impossible for flexible hose connections to be
           mismatched.

12.13      Primary Suspension
12.13.1.   The primary suspension shall be self-retained, and shall not dislodge when a
           wheel set is replaced from below.


12.13.2.   If achieved at the primary suspension, an easy mean shall be provide to adjust
           the height of the primary suspension in order to compensate for wheel wear.
           The above height adjustment shall be able to carry out in a maintenance pit
           where no drop table or hoist equipment is available.


12.13.3.   If chevron type spring is used as the primary suspension, a positive mean of

Section 12, page 12-18


           axle containment shall be provided to prevent derailment when the chevron
           spring is collapsed (for example, due to the excessive heat built up as a result
           of journal bearing seizure).


12.14      Traction Gear Units And Drive Couplings


12.14.1.   Gear unit shall be provided to transmit the torque from the traction motors to
           the Subway Car axles.


12.14.2.   Parallel drives arrangement shall be provided. The gears shall be lubricated by
           a direct oil splash system.


12.14.3.   A flexible couplings shall be provided in the drive train in order to
           accommodate the relative movement of the drive train components. The
           motors shall be fully suspended in all instances, such that all the motor weight
           shall be sprung, and drove the gear unit through ring gears. The unsprung
           mass of the motor/gear unit assembly shall be kept to a minimum.


12.14.4.   Due consideration shall be given to the design of the motor mounting in such
           a way that there shall be no failure leading to motor fell to the track and
           causing the derailment, say, due to bearing failure in the gearbox results in
           very high loading on the motor fixing bolts. The safety brackets shall be able
           to fully retaining the motor.


12.14.5.   Suitable orifices and plugs shall be provided in the gear units for lubrication
           adding and draining; the filler hole shall be positioned at the maximum fill
           level. A breather or labyrinth type seal shall be provided and arranged to
           prevent the entrance of water.


12.14.6.   The gear unit shall be designed to prevent oil leakage around the high and low
           speed shafts.


12.14.7.   When assembled, the gears and pinions shall be adjusted to bear with the

proper amount of back-lash which shall have been indelibly marked on the
           gear at the point of manufacture. Adjustment of the clearance shall not be
           required                           in                          service .


           When assembled, the gears and pinions shall have the proper amount of back-
           lash. Adjustment of the clearance shall not be required in service.


12.14.8.   The drive coupling from the traction motor to the gear unit shall be suitably
           balanced so that no objectionable noise or vibration is produced within the
           Subway Car at speeds up to 88 km/h (55 MPH) with wheels ranging from new
           to fully worn. The design of the gear unit shall be able to accommodate lateral,
           vertical, longitudinal and angular motion of the axle relative to the traction
           motor as required without imposing stress on its armature bearings.

12.14.9.   The gear units shall be so designed that under all operating conditions,
           adequate lubrication will be provided to all gears and bearings. The design of
           the shaft and the seal shall be suitable for corrosive environments. A quill type
           arrangement (corrosion resistant sleeve) shall be used for assembly of the gear
           unit to the axle. Due consideration shall be given on the lip seals to prevent
           the pumping effect i.e. either pumping contaminants into the gearbox, or
           pumping                               lubricant                            out .




12.14.10. Magnetic plugs shall be installed in the drain holes of the gear units.


12.14.11. The design of the gear unit shall be able to prevent dangerous rotation of the

         understanding that performance could be affected (namely humidity and
         internal CO2 level).


   (c)   In the event of a loss of the emergency power supply, the dampers system
         shall default to the specified mode.

          Montréal Protocol shall be used and the Contractor shall submit details of the
          proposed refrigerant for approval.


15.15.2   A sight glass shall be fitted in the refrigerant liquid line to show the refrigerant
          flow and be visible from the saloon area through an inspection hole accessible
          from the return air plenum.


15.15.3   Non-ferrous and corrosion resistant material shall be used for the associated
          piping and fittings in the refrigerant circuit.

Section 15, page 15-13


15.15.4   Screw couplings will be permitted only where necessary to disconnecting the
          refrigerant circuit for maintenance. Automatic shut off facilities shall be
          provided with the couplings to prevent loss of refrigerant for the
          disconnection. All other connections shall be of a permanent type.


15.15.5   The refrigeration piping system shall be effectively dehydrated prior to
          charging.


15.15.6   A dehydration device shall be installed in the refrigerant circuit and shall have
          sufficient capacity to absorb any moisture entering the system during overhaul.
          The dehydrator shall not require servicing between overhauls.


15.15.7   High sensitivity moisture indicator shall be provided with colour change to
          indicate the status.


15.15.8   Means shall be provided to avoid loss of refrigerant to atmosphere during
          charging and extraction.


15.15.9   Facilities shall be provided to allow the refrigerant to be pumped down
          partially to the liquid receiver and partially into the condenser coil before shut
          down of the system (refer to PS 9.3.2).




15.16     Condensate Drainage


15.16.1   The Contractor shall submit the sizing and arrangement of condensate
          drainage to adequately collect and drain condensate without spillage.


15.16.2   Outlets of the condensate drain shall be arranged to avoid dripping on the
          running rails.


15.16.3   The Contractor shall take into consideration the drainage arrangement in depot

as specified in Clause 2.3 of Appendix I Annex 5.


15.16.4   For those roof-mounted equipments, they shall seat on a sealed arrangement
          designed to avoid any water getting into the saloon area, under any operating
          or non-operating condition.


15.16.5   The floors of any unit shall be as flat as possible, and without obstruction
          which could lead to the collection of pools of water. The floors and sides of
          the units shall be completely sealed, and adequately drained to prevent
          penetration of water into the saloon.


15.16.6   The exterior of the drain pan and drain pipes shall be insulated to prevent
          condensation on the cold surface.

15.16.7   The use of flexible hose to connect the drainage pipes from the HVAC unit to

15.16.8   The drainage arrangement shall be integrated with the sealed pan design and
