15.18     Ducting


15.18.1   Ducting shall be provided so that each cab is provided with either heating /
          cooled (under normal operation) or ventilating (under emergency or smoke
          modes of operation) air for the comfort of the Operator. A suitable manual
          control shall be provided for easy adjustment of the air flow (refer to PS
          8.12.1). The cab shall have a minimum air circulation rate of 170 m /h (100
          ft /min) under all modes of operation


15.18.2   The saloon ducting shall be designed to achieve uniform discharge along the
          whole length of the car. The supply air speed shall be limited to avoid

discomfort due to direct draughts.


15.18.3   The ducts shall be thermally and acoustically insulated. No condensation shall
          occur on the duct exterior surfaces, ceiling panel or air supply outlets. The
          insulation arrangement shall be submitted for approval. The ducts and plenum
          chambers shall be designed to avoid dust traps.


          The ducts shall be thermally and acoustically insulated as required to maintain
          interior heating and noise level requirements. No condensation shall occur on
          the duct exterior surfaces, ceiling panel or air supply outlets. The insulation
          arrangement shall be submitted for approval. The ducts and plenum chambers
          shall be designed to avoid dust traps.

15.21     Heating System


15.21.1   Heating for the cab and saloon shall be provided by baseboard heaters and
          overhead heaters. In addition to these heaters, the cab area shall be also

provided with a forced-air heater unit. The saloon baseboard heaters shall be
          located along the side of the car and underneath the seats. Due consideration
          shall be given to the design of the baseboard heater air grille, such that the air
          grille surface shall be easily cleanable and the edges shall integrate with the
          floor smoothly to ensure no dirt traps are present. For those seats that are
          located at the gangway end, if seat plinth is provided, the baseboard heater
          shall be located inside the seat plinths and the air grills shall be aesthetically
          integrated with the seat plinth. Additional heater shall be provided for the door
          threshold. For safety reason, all heater temperatures shall not exceed 55 C.


15.21.2   The baseboard and overhead heaters shall be automatically controlled by the
          HVAC system control unit with over-temperature protection provided. The

Section 15, page 15-17


          cab forced-air heater shall be independently operated and thermostatically
          controlled.


15.21.3   Baseboard heaters shall be limited in power such that the temperature of the
          surface which can, under normal conditions come in contact with passengers
          shall not exceed 55°C (131°F) at nominal supply voltage in an ambient
          temperature of 18ºC (65°F). Localized hot spots which may be contacted by a
          passenger may not exceed 60°C (140°F).


15.21.4   The overall design of the baseboard heaters and the air grills shall be such a
          way that there shall be no entry of combustible material, such as newspaper
          and other material commonly found in transit vehicles, to the element from
          any direction. The heater enclosure shall be easily removable for cleaning out
          any debris on regular basis. The securing fasteners shall be stainless steel.


15.21.5   The interior heating element of the baseboard heaters shall attain a surface
          temperature of not greater than 200°C (392°F) at nominal supply voltage in an
          ambient temperature of 18°C (65°F).


15.21.6   The heating equipment shall be easily accessible inside the saloon for
          maintenance and removal, but inaccessible to the passengers.




15.22     Maintainability


15.22.1   General


   (a)    Maintenance of the HVAC system shall be consistent with the car
          maintenance philosophy given in PS 26. In particular HVAC components
          shall have a minimum life equal to the maintenance period of the truck and
          preferably a multiple of the maintenance period.


   (b)    Apart from unit replacement, no periodic maintenance access from the roof
          shall be required. For those equipments that are mounted in the saloon, for
          example, air return filter, shall be accessible from inside the saloon.

15.22.2   HVAC system Changing


   (a)    The HVAC system shall be capable of being disconnected and reconnected
          easily and with a minimum of operations by personnel working in roof. It
          shall be possible to easily inspect for correct reconnection without the need for
          special tools or instruments.


   (b)    The design of the HVAC system shall provide for ease of interchanging. It
          shall be possible to change either HVAC unit on a Subway Car and release the
          Subway Car for service using existing Commission shop facilities within three

Section 15, page 15-18


          hours using two trained maintainers. HVAC units shall be completely
          interchangeable between cars without the need to adjust any components.


   (c)    The design shall provide ease of HVAC unit changing using the Commission's
          existing hoisting facilities. Following a HVAC system changeout, it shall be
          possible to restore the Subway Car to a condition fit for service operation at

15.22.3   Inspection


          It shall be possible for personnel working in pits or alongside the HVAC
          system to visually inspect the condition of components easily just by opening
          the unit cover, and without the use of special tools.


15.22.4   Cleaning


          The unit arrangement shall be designed to allow equipment such as coil, of
          being cleaned using high pressure hot water and steam jet cleaning equipment,
          with and without high efficiency detergents. All closed sections and pockets
          shall be self draining or sealed against water intrusion.


15.22.5   Handling


          Lifting attachments shall be provided for handling a complete HVAC unit.

   (b)   An emergency detrainment door shall be provided at the front of each driving
         cab (refer to PS 8.16).


   (c)   A partition door shall be provided between each driving cab and the saloon.


   (d)   One pair of manually operated cab bodyside doors shall be provided on each
         side of each cab (refer to PS 8.15.4).


   ( e ) The passenger doors shall be designed to using for reference the AUTHORITY

         taken into consideration the seating spatial arrangement as described in PS
         7.6.1, shall be submitted for approval.


   (f)   Apart from replacement of door panel, no maintenance access shall be
         required from the outside of the saloon.


16.1.2   Construction


   (a)   Reference in this Section to power supplies means the electrical supply
         required for door power operation and control functions.


   (b)   The exterior doors shall be of robust design and construction, capable of
         withstanding the specified design loadings, and be impact resistant (refer to

PS 16.2.5(a)) and durable with minimal maintenance requirements.


(c)   All components and equipment that are accessible to the passengers during
      any part of the door operating cycle shall be vandal resistant.


(d)   The doors shall be designed to prevent ingress of water in severe storm
      conditions which are usually encountered in the CITY area and during
      washing in an automated wash plant.


(e)   Gutters shall be provided above all bodyside doors to protect staff, passengers,
      saloon and cab interiors, and door operating mechanisms, from water running
      off the roof.


(f)   Under no circumstance shall it be possible for the doors to become jammed or

Section 16, page 16-3


         fail to close under any condition of car loading.


16.1.3   Safety


   (a)   The design of the door system as a whole, together with the interfaces with
         carbody, shall not cause any injury to the passengers, train operator or station
         operator under any normal operating conditions. Due consideration shall be
         given to minimising the possibility of human error causing injury due to mis-
         operation.


   (b)   Door control and operating arrangements shall be designed to fail to a safe
         condition with no hidden failure.


   (c)   No single component failure shall result in an unsafe failure mode, such as a
         door being powered open in the absence of a valid "open" command.


   (d)   The Contractor shall demonstrate, by a combination of attention to the design
         detail of the leading edge of the door and appropriate actuation and control
         facilities, the ability of the door systems to reduce the risk of entrapment to a
         minimum and eliminate the risk of a train being released to start with an
         obstruction between any door leaves.


   (e)   The Contractor shall ensure that the doors will be operated within the
         specified kinematic envelope under all normal operating conditions.


   (f)   The status of each door shall be monitored by the TIMS which shall detect
         and report emerging door problems (refer to PS 10.5.4).


   (g)   The door system, in particularly the carbody and door leaf interface, shall be
         designed to prevent passenger injury due to the entrapment of body during the
         opening and closing movements of the doors.


16.1.4   Acoustic and Vibration


   (a)   Consideration shall be given in the design of the doors to the overall acoustic

performance of the train as specified.


(b)   The doors installation shall be quiet in operation and shall be free of all
      "rattle", "squeak", "whistle", "slamming" and other inappropriate
      operationally generated noise, or train movement induced noise.


(c)   All elements of the doors installation (fixed and moving) shall be sufficiently
      rigid to avoid generation of noise by panel excitation as a result of train or air
      movement.


(d)   All arrangements for movement shall incorporate noise and vibration control
      wherever practicable. Details of the proposed noise and vibration control

Section 16, page 16-4


         measures shall be submitted for approval prior to commencement of
         fabrication.


16.1.5   The design and operating features of all types of doors shall be submitted for

16.2     Passenger Bodyside Door


16.2.1   Spatial Arrangement


         A clear opening of not less than 1 524 mm (5') wide and 1 930 mm (6' 4")
         high, shall be provided on each passenger door of each car.


16.2.2   Door Panel Construction


   (a)   The exterior and interior surfaces of the doors shall be finished in accordance
         with the agreed external livery and interior design (refer to PS 6).


   (b)   The door panel shall be resistant to normal detergents and chemicals such as
         dilute phosphoric and oxalic acids or similar, used for internal and external car
         cleaning.


   (c)   The doors shall be free from surface defects such as dimples, warping, spot
         welding depressions and blemishes.


   (d)   The doors shall be provided with fixed flush fitted single glazed windows to
         the colour specified in PS 6.


   (e)   The door panel shall be designed to avoid the possibility of any ingress of
         water into, and the formation of condensate within, the door structure.


   (f)   No electrical equipment shall be located on any door panel.

(g)   The maximum weight of a saloon door panel shall not exceed 50 kg.


   (h)   The door panel shall be designed to last for the life of the train without major
         refurbishment required. In designing to achieve this the Contractor shall give
         due consideration to the climatic conditions in CITY as specified.


16.2.3   Sealing Arrangement


   (a)   The sealing arrangement between the door leaves and the carbody shall avoid
         any finger trapping or causing any injury to passengers during door opening or
         closing operations.


   (b)   The doors shall be fully sealed when closed to meet the specified acoustic

Section 16, page 16-5



          requirements and the water tightness requirement as stated in PS 16.1.2 (d).
   (c)    The door panel seals shall be non-contact when the door is moving.


   ( d ) The seals shall not impede operation of the door and they shall have adequate
         operating clearances and adjustment to ensure that scuffing of the bodyside
         and panels of the doors does not occur in operation.


   ( e ) The seals shall be securely fixed by an approved means, avoiding the use of
         loose fasteners or adhesive. They shall be easily replaceable and adjustable
         and shall not allow the build up of dirt or moisture. All fixings to door seals
         shall be concealed.


   ( f ) The door nose rubber shall be designed in such a way that they shall be easily
          replaceable and adjustable without removal of the door panel from the car.


16.2.4    Door Operating Mechanism Construction


   (a)    All components and systems, such as rollers, racks, gears and pinions, not
          intended for passengers use, shall be inaccessible to passengers at all times,
          including during the door operating cycle.


   (b)    The mechanism shall be simple with the number of moving parts kept to a
          minimum.


   (c)    The door mechanism including guides shall be arranged so that no objects can
          become trapped and prevent door operation.


   (d)    For all operating modes and under all power supply conditions, door
          movements shall be smooth, controlled and without jerks or any violent
          motion.


   (e)    No part of the doors, door installation, door control systems or any other door
          system components shall be damaged, or have their service life shortened by
          repeated or continuous stalling by obstructions, or pushing back of the doors
          by passengers.

(f)   Each mechanism shall be mounted on a rigid frame that can be adjusted for
         alignment in situ, and removed from the car as an integral unit.


   (g)   The operating mechanism shall be housed inside the car and the design shall
         provide for ease of access for maintenance.

16.2.7   Mechanical Lock

         automatically when the door open controls are legitimately operated or when
         the manual release device is operated (refer to PS 16.2.10).


   (c)   The operation of the lock relative to the door opening cycle shall ensure
         release before the commencement of the cycle and engagement on closure,
         with or without the availability of power. Door status shall be monitored by
         the individual door control unit.


   (d)   When the lock is released, it shall be possible to push/slide open the door from
         inside or outside the saloon.


   (e)   The door leading edge seals shall be configured in such a way, utilizing
         interlocking mating arrangements, that the locking devices shall not engage in
         the presence of small obstruction of maximum thickness 3 mm at any height
         of application using the measurement gauge as shown in the Contract
         Drawing No. NST 077.


   (f)   Each mechanical lock shall be fitted with a sensor to prove that the door is

         locked. The status of the mechanical lock shall be monitored by the TIMS.
   (g)   The mechanical lock shall not require lubrication between overhauls.

(h)   The mechanical lock shall be spring loaded and energised to release.

          converter to be re-started after a trip of the line contactor. Repeatedly
          operating this reset facility shall not cause any damage to the auxiliary
          converter. However, it may be considered as acceptable for a converter to not
          resume its power conversion duty if there are still thermal conditions or
          persistent failures which could endanger the life of the equipment or the
          powered loads.


   (d)    In the event of one auxiliary converter not operating, the DC output shall
          prevent discharging of the battery (refer to PS 17.2.1(c)).

          operator in the controlling cab.

19.6       Fault Scenarios Simulation
19.6.4     The Contractor shall provide simulation of a comprehensive list of fault
           scenarios and abnormal situations for trainee to drill on the recovery
           procedures.


19.6.5     A minimum of 100 fault scenarios shall be able to be stored and run on the
           CABSIM.


19.6.6     Each fault scenario shall be controllable either by the pre-defined information
           in the exercise, or during the running of an exercise via the instructor's
           console.


19.6.7     Fault scenario shall have the following possible status:


   (a)     Inserted - fault scenario is inserted into the simulated train and shall become
           active when the activation condition(s) is met (for example train overrun shall
           become active when train starts to stop at a station)


   (b)     Active - activation condition(s) is met and effects of the fault scenario shall
           appear


   (c)     Overcome - correct recovery procedures taken but the root cause of the fault

scenario is not be removed (for example locked wheels with brake isolated)


(d)   Cleared - correct recovery procedures taken and root cause of the fault
      scenario is removed (for example train stopped short and moved to correct
      stopping point in CM by trainee)


(e)   Cleared by Instructor - correct recovery procedures not taken and fault
      scenario has been removed by the instructor via the instructor's console


(f)   Cleared by System - correct recovery procedures not taken and fault scenario
      removed automatically by the system without instructor's intervention and
      applicable for exercise of training type only.

Section 19, page 19-17


19.6.8   Each fault scenario shall have the following information fields:


   (a)   Activation Criteria - define the conditions including time delay upon which
         the fault scenario shall become active after it is inserted


   (b)   Symptoms - the audio, visual and train behavioural symptoms when fault
         scenario become active


   (c)   Overcome / Clear Criteria - define the recovery procedure (step or
         combination of steps with a particular sequence) to be taken in order to
         overcome / clear the fault active scenario


   (d)   Standard Time - standard handling time for performing the recovery
         procedure


   (e)   Tolerance Time - a percentage of the standard time which defines the
         maximum time beyond which defect handling time shall be given zero mark


   (f)   Extensive Delay Limitation - a percentage of the tolerance time beyond which
         exercise of qualification type shall be stopped automatically, and the trainee
         deemed to have failed.

Section 20   Materials And Workmanship
Requirements

20.1 General


20.1.1.   This Section of PS covers materials and workmanship requirements for the
          train system.


20.1.2.   The standards and practices detailed in this Section of PS shall be observed as
          the minimum requirements which are acceptable to the Engineer.


20.1.3.   The Contractor may offer alternative standards which are equivalent to or
          better than those herein, and which the Contractor shall justify to the
          satisfaction of the Engineer.


20.1.4.   The Contractor shall adopt the up-to-date best practice and workmanship to
          execute the Works to the highest standards and to the satisfaction of the
          Engineer.


20.1.5.   Whenever the PS, Drawings or directions/instructions of the Engineer admit
          of a reasonable doubt about what is permissible and when they fail to state the
          quality of any work, the interpretation which requires the best quality of work
          is to be followed.


20.2 Materials
20.2.1.   Materials used in the construction of the train shall not constitute a health
          hazard for passengers, staff or the public. Prohibited materials shall include
          but shall not be limited to the following:
   (a)    Asbestos
   (b)    Lead based pigment paints

(c)    Halogens in greater concentrations than those specified in PS 21.10.


          The use of all materials shall be submitted for approval.


20.2.2.   All materials used on the vehicles shall be of a Limited Fire Hazard type to
          the requirements of PS 21.10 except fuel, transmission oil and lubricants.


20.2.3.   The Contractor shall consider at all stages of SEMP, the specification of all
          materials with regard to their health and safety impact both in handling, use
          and disposal, and in this regard shall be incorporated into the Workplace
          Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) according to Canada's
          hazard communication standard. The key elements of the WHMIS shall be

Section 20, page 20-4



          comprised of cautionary labelling of containers of WHMIS "controlled
          products", the provision of material safety data sheets (MSDSs) and worker
          education programs.


20.2.4.   The Contractor shall consider at all stages of SEMP, the specification of all
          materials with regard to their environmental impact both in use and upon
          eventual disposal, and in this regard shall incorporate into the Environmental
          Management Plan according to PS 28.4.


20.2.5.   A schedule of all materials used shall be regularly updated and submitted and
          shall include the following:-
   (a)    Composition
   (b)    Quantity (kg)
   (c)    Life Expectancy
   (d)    Items that would be re-cycled at mid-life refurbishment and at life expiry
   (e)    Means of disposal and environmental effect of this disposal
   (f)    Labelling with regards to composition and hazard


20.2.6.   In addition to the materials used during construction the schedule (refer to PS
          20.2.5) shall also list materials used in the maintenance and cleaning of the
          trains, their usage rates and disposal procedures.


20.3 Materials Testing
20.3.1.   Fire Performance


   (a)    The Contractor shall supply and maintain a schedule of non-metallic materials
          used in the construction of the trains under the Configuration Management
          requirements (refer to PS 21.3.10(b)).


   (b)    This schedule shall give information in respect of the fire certification of the
          materials and groupings of materials in assemblies (copies of which shall be
          supplied), the national or international standard applicable to the material, its
          location, the amounts used and its calorific value including fire load and

average power output.


(c)   The schedule shall include a fire load calculation for the train. This latter
      feature will be used to highlight materials with particular fire hazard potential
      so that special attention can be paid to the fire test results, with a view to
      ensuring that this potential is not realised.


(d)   The schedule shall be audited periodically in line with the Systems Assurance
      Plan (refer to PS 25).


(e)   Triplicate testing, generally to ISO 5660: Part 1 or ASTM E 1354, shall be
      carried out for materials/composites which form major and/or significant

Section 20, page 20-5



          surfaces within the saloons. To determine if surface is significant, use the
          NFPA 130 section 8.4.1.5.10 definition. The reports, if performed before NTP,
          must have been performed a maximum of 5 years before the NTP. The report
          shall be supplied with a letter confirming the material tested is identical, in
          composition and manufacturing process, to the material supplied for this
          contract. For reports performed after the NTP, the report shall include a photo
          showing the sample installation in the test arrangement.


   (f)    Where composites are used, eg. seat trim, these shall be tested at the
          maximum convenient thickness (25mm) and shall be as closely representative
          of the item concerned as possible.


   (g)    In addition to the standard test house report, the report will include the data
          from each test and shall be supplied in an electronic format on a CD-ROM.


   (h)    The materials/composites tested shall be representative of the surfaces listed
          below and shall be tested at the stated input radiation (flux). In each test the
          scan time shall be 2.0 s and the test duration shall not be less than 1200 s
          irrespective of the sample behaviour.


          Surface            Flux kWm-2


          Floor              20
          Wall               35
          Ceiling            50
          Seat Shell Back    35
          Seat Shell Base    50
          Seat Trim Back     35
          Seat Trim Base     20


20.3.2.   Power Output on Flash-Over Fires


   (a)    The Contractor shall carry out prediction and final evaluation on the power
          output from flash over fire in the associated SEMP stages according to PS
          21.10.8.

(b)   An analytical method based on the summation of rates of heat release shall be
      used to determine the maximum power output of fire. Definition of heat
      release rate shall refer to NFPA 130 and the data of heat release rates of each
      material shall be obtained by an actual testing in the cone calorimeter.


(c)   The total nominal heat release rate of all surface materials in a car, when
      summed together, shall not exceed 9 MW per car on flash-over fires.


(d)   The Contractor shall submit for approval calculations, by using well accepted
      computer modeling techniques to demonstrate that the requirements of
      maximum power output of fire are achieved under all foreseeable worse case

Section 20, page 20-6



          scenarios. All assumptions that have been made in the above model shall be
          specified with justification. The initiation fire, or design fire, shall be 100kW
          according to BS 6853. Alternative definition of initiation fire shall be
          submitted for Approval.


   (e)    The modeling technique shall be based on the acceptable method, such as,
          ISO 9705 - Room Fire Test in which the walls and ceilings are lined with test
          materials to represent a section of a rail car and subjected to fires of controlled
          sizes, shall be adopted.


20.3.3.   Suitability of Materials


   (a)    Where materials used in the construction of the vehicles are not specified to

   (c)    The Contractor shall have submitted with its proposal a general precis of its

20.3.4.   Certification

   (b)    The documentation shall be held by the Contractor or its Subcontractor as

20.4.2.   Definitions

The following definitions shall apply:


Heavy Current :   Currents in excess of 30 A.


Light Current :   Currents of 30 A or less.


High Voltage :    In excess of 300 V, to earth.


Low Voltage :     300 V or less, to earth.


Auxiliary Contact :       A contact in a low voltage circuit.

Section 20, page 20-10



          Power Contact : A contact which is not covered by the definition of
          auxiliary contact.


          Enclosure :        A closed space in which equipment is mounted.


          Contact Enclosure :        A small enclosure in which auxiliary contacts only
          are mounted.


          Terminal : A fixed point to which a conductor can be attached to form a
          connection.


          Termination :       A device fixed to a cable or other conductor to enable it to
          be attached to a terminal.


20.4.3.   General Requirements


   (a)    All equipment shall be constructed in a sufficiently robust manner, and
          arranged so as not to suffer deterioration, wear, or damage due to vibration or
          shock loads encountered in traction service.


   (b)    Equipment shall be arranged into groups where practicable, the items of any
          one group being mounted on a common frame or the equivalent, complete
          with such as wiring and piping.


   (c)    All equipment shall be protected against damage such as those caused by dirt,
          dust and moisture.


20.4.4.   Corrosion Protection


   (a)    The Contractor shall submit for approval a system to provide corrosion
          protection for the life of the train.


   (b)    The Contractor shall take into consideration that all equipment shall be

operated under a prevailing severe weather and corrosive ambient conditions
          found in CITY.


   (c)    Where necessary, closed or inaccessible areas shall be internally covered with
          an adequate corrosion protection coating immediately after completion of
          fabrication.


   (d)    All corrosion protection measures shall be permanent without causing any
          contamination.


20.5 Interchangeability
20.5.1.   The Contractor shall minimize the number of different equipment models on

Section 20, page 20-11



          the train. As far as practicable, the same model of equipment shall be used to
          fulfill similar functions at different applications. For example, the same relay
          model may be employed to fulfill similar switching functions in different
          circuits.


20.5.2.   Equipment items or components of the same model shall be readily
          interchangeable. They shall be designed and manufactured so that no
          additional fitting, machining, adjustment or modification, other than those
          approved by the Engineer, would be necessary during replacement.


          This is particularly important, such as in the case of covers, bearing caps,
          equipment mountings and door leaves, which will be replaced or interchanged
          frequently among different locations after maintenance work. At the request of
          the Engineer, the Contractor shall provide demonstration on any specified
          equipment to show that such requirement is satisfied.


20.5.3.   In cases where the same mounting arrangement, such as an electrical plug or
          pneumatic valve, is provided on different equipment which are not
          interchangeable, the Contractor shall design the mountings so that the
          equipment will not be mixed up during installation.


          This shall be achieved by providing suitable identification devices such as
          colour coding or special markings. The use of such devices shall be submitted
          for approval. Should the Engineer consider such devices inadequate, the
          Contractor shall provide a non interchangeable design to make wrong
          installation impossible.


20.5.4.   The requirement in Clause 5.3 above shall also apply to cases where it is
          possible to install or assemble an equipment item in a number of different
          orientations, such as mating halves of a housing, non-symetrical cams on a
          shaft.
20.5.5.   Any assembly, sub-assembly module or part which requires setting up, re-
          alignment or matching to restore full system capability, shall be identified and
          clearly highlighted in the related section of the maintenance manual.


20.5.6.   Bolted Joints and Fasteners

(a)   All fasteners supplied by the Contractor for vehicle assembly shall be in ISO
      Metric size. Proprietary equipment may use Imperial fasteners, subject to the
      approval of the Engineer. The following standards shall be applied where
      appropriate :


      BS 3692 for hexagonal bolts, screws and nuts
      BS 4183 for machine screws & nuts
      BS 4174 for self tapping screws
      BS 1574 for split cotter pins

          BS 4929 for prevailing torque nuts


   ( b ) Due consideration shall be given in the design stage to the tolerance of
         components to ensure interchangeability of components. The use of fitted
         bolts shall be minimise and shall only be used subject to approval.


   ( c ) For permanent fixings connections or those where dismantling is unlikely, two
         piece rivets such as AVDELOK or HUCKBOLT or other similar fasteners
         shall be used subject to approval. Blind fasteners such as BOM rivets or
         similar shall be avoided for structural connections, and only used subject to
         the approval of the Engineer.


   ( d ) For fixings connections which will be dismantled for maintenance, the
         following methods shall be used.


20.6 Bolt connection
20.6.1.   Bolted connection shall use documented torque tightening procedures and
          shall be submitted for approval. Hexagon head bolts Grade 8.8 and nuts Grade
          8 shall be used. Where secondary locking is required, which include all
          structural bolted joints and bolted joints subjected to high levels of vibration,
          prevailing torque nuts to BS 4929 shall be used.


20.6.2.   Setscrews (Grade 8.8) and stud connections (Grade 8.8 studs with grade 8
          prevailing torque nuts to BS 4929) shall only be used where it is not possible
          to make a bolted connection. The use and the proposed method of locking
          shall be submitted for approval.


20.6.3.   Washers shall not be used except where the nut is tightened onto a soft surface
          or for connections designed for interchangeability i.e. slotted holes. Spring
          washers shall be avoided.


20.6.4.   Mating surfaces shall be machined flat and shall be clean and free from paint
          or rust.

20.6.5.   Suitable precautions, which shall be subject to approval, shall be taken to
          prevent corrosion in joints involving dissimilar metals.


20.6.6.   Tapped holes in aluminium shall, in all cases, be provided with suitable thread
          inserts. Items of proprietary equipment which are normally supplied without
          wire thread inserts may be exempted from this requirement, subject to
          approval


20.6.7.   Where tab washers are proposed the material chosen shall be sufficiently hard
          to prevent settlement of the joint and consequent loss of bolt preload. Mild
          steel tab washers shall not be used.

20.6.8.   The Contractors torque tightening procedure shall include provision for
          marking torque tightened fasteners with coloured paint to indicate that the
          torque tightening procedure has been correctly carried out.



20.7 Welding
20.7.1.   General


   (a)    All welding work shall be under the control of a suitably qualified welding
          engineer nominated by the Contractor as his representative.


   (b)    All welding equipment shall conform to relevant national or international
          standards which shall be subject to approval.



   (c)    Permanent backing strips shall not be used unless otherwise approved.
20.7.2.   Standards


   (a)    Welding of carbon and carbon/manganese steel shall be to the requirements of
          BS 5135 (if not applicable, replacement by BS EN 1011-1:1998 and BS EN
          1011-2:2001 is acceptable) for wrought steel and BS 4570 for cast steel.


   (b)    Welding of aluminium and aluminium alloys shall be to the requirements of
          BS 3019 : Part 1 and BS 3571 : Part 1 as appropriate (if not applicable,
          replacement by BS EN 1011-4-2000 is acceptable).


   (c)    Standards for materials and processes not covered by the specifications given
          in Clauses 7.2.1 and 7.2.2 shall be submitted for approval.


20.7.3.   Materials


   (a)    All materials shall be clearly identified and shall have certificates of chemical
          composition and mechanical properties which shall be held by the Contractor.

(b)    Materials shall be free from laminations and lamellar defects.


   (c)    Fusion faces in the areas to be welded shall be prepared for 25 mm surface
          and both side shall be free from paint, rust and other contaminants. Any
          solvents used to achieve this shall be thoroughly dried off prior to welding.

            8:2002 and BS EN 1418:1998 is acceptable). Following satisfactory

   (b)      Welding consumable shall be such that the mechanical properties of the

20.9.1.    All bearings and pivots shall be of ample proportions to withstand shock loads

           operating current value closely related to the current demand of the current-

           using equipment connected or intended to be connected to it and to the current

   (c)     A fault on one circuit shall not result in the shutting down of any unrelated

20.11.5.   General Requirements


   (a)     Each circuit shall be provided with means of interrupting the supply on load

   (e)     Single phase loads in an installation with three phase supply shall be evenly
           and reasonably distributed among the phases.


21.11.6.   Current Demand


   (a)     The current rating of a circuit shall not be less than the current demand of the
           circuit.


   ( b ) The current demand of a circuit shall be the same as the rating of the
         overcurrent protective device of the circuit.

( c ) The nominal current or current setting of the devices shall not be less than the
      design current of the circuit.


( d ) The nominal current or current setting of the devices shall not exceed the
      lowest of the current-carrying capacities of any of the conductors in the circuit.


( e ) The current causing effective operation of the devices shall not exceed 1.45
      times the lowest of the current-carrying capacities of any of the conductors of
      the circuit.


( f ) Sufficient safety margin shall also be provided on determining the current
       rating of a circuit.
