20.15.7    Terminals shall be of the steel screwed post type securely moulded into an

insulating base. All power terminations on one stud shall be assembled
          together without intervening, such as nuts and washers. Studs or bolts shall
          not be used to carry current.


20.15.8   Alternative forms of terminals will be considered where appropriate but post
          terminals are mandatory for safety circuits.


20.15.9   Terminal posts or the equivalent shall be mounted horizontally or vertically
          downwards. Vertical posts shall only be used if the posts are completely
          shielded from the possibility of being bridged by a conducting object dropped
          onto or lying across the terminals. Horizontal posts shall be so arranged that
          there is little possibility of an object lying across two posts. Failure of a fixed
          terminal shall not result in scrapping of a complete piece of equipment.

Section 20, page 20-33




20.15.10   Cables terminating in plugs or sockets may be secured by soldering where the
           plug is too small for crimping to be practicable and a suitable cable clamp
           provided.


20.15.11 Terminals and terminal boxes shall be so arranged that water collecting in
           ducts and conduits cannot reach live parts.


20.15.12   Terminals for circuits of different voltages shall be kept in separate groups.
           Negative and neutral terminals shall be grouped separately.


20.15.13   Cable glands shall securely retain without damaging the outer sheath of the
           cables.


20.15.14   Electrical connections shall not be used as the sole means of mechanical
           support for components other than those mounted on printed circuit boards.
           Contactors and other equipment which are specifically designed to be
           mounted via its electrical connections is exempt from this requirement
           provided that the appropriate manufacturers data sheets are submitted for
           information to the Engineer.


20.16.Cable Enclosure
20.16      Cable enclosures as protective conductors


20.16.1    Types of protective conductors, such as circuit protective conductors, earthing
           conductors, of which shall be formed by rigid steel conduits, trunking or
           ducting.


20.16.2    Metallic enclosures where used as protective conductors shall:


   (a)     Have a cross-sectional area according to BS 7671;

(b)    Have an electrical continuity achieved and maintained to afford protection
          against mechanical, chemical or electrochemical deterioration; and


   (c)    Permit the connection of other protective conductors at every predetermined
          tap-off point.


20.16.3   All cable enclosures shall be properly supported and of a type suitable for any
          risk of mechanical damage to which they may be liable in normal conditions
          of service or adequately protected against such damage.


20.16.4   Where cable enclosures pass through fire barriers, the opening made shall be
          sealed according to the appropriate degree of fire resistance.

Section 20, page 20-34



20.16.5   Where cable enclosures are not used as protective conductors, the non-
          metallic enclosures can be used provided that the material used shall comply
          with the specified fire requirements.


20.17.Conduit - Trunking and Ducting
20.17     Conduit


20.17.1   Conduit shall be of an approved non-metallic grade except where high
          mechanical strength or electrical continuity is a requirement.


20.17.2   Metallic conduit where approved shall be of solid drawn seamless zinc coated
          steel or aluminium EMT.


20.17.3   The conduit and fittings shall comply with BS4568 Screwed type, Class 4 or
          equivalent.


20.17.4   The nominal minimum outside diameter of any rigid conduit to be used shall
          be 16mm with a minimum wall thickness of 1.4mm.


20.17.5   The outlets of all metallic conduits shall be protected by suitable bushes. All
          steel conduits, conduit fittings and the associated metallic boxes for the
          enclosure of electrical accessories shall be protected against corrosion on both
          the inside and outside surfaces.


20.17.6   An adequate number of suitably sized adaptable boxes shall be provided in
          conduit installation to enable cables to be drawn in easily and without damage.


20.17.7   Conduits in exposed locations shall be provided with an effective means of
          sealing the cable entry to prevent the ingress of water and condensed moisture.

20.17.8   The use of flexible conduits which have been service proven, shall be used
          across movable vibration or thermal isolation joints.


20.17.9   Flexible conduits shall be PMA-type or flexible steel. If flexible steel conduits
          are used, flexible steel conduits shall comply with BS 731 Part 1 (if not
          applicable, replacement by BS EN 61386-1:2004 is acceptable) or equivalent.
          In addition, the flexible steel conduits shall be of the metallic water tight
          pattern with oversheath.


20.17.10 Workmanship


   (a)    Conduits shall not be bent in such a manner which appreciably distorts their
          original cross-sectional shape or causes damage to the conduits.

Section 20, page 20-35



   ( b ) Burrs, sharp edges and projections shall be removed from the internal surfaces
         and ends of conduits, ducting or other enclosures when installed.


   ( c ) Where the protective coating on a metallic enclosure has been damaged after
          installation, such surface shall be effectively restored by paint or other suitable
          coating to prevent corrosion.



20.18 Trunking
20.18.1   Trunking and fittings shall comply with the requirements specified in BS 4678
          part 1 or equivalent.


20.18.2   Trunking installations shall be constructed using manufacturer's standard
          fittings such as tee or angle pieces, throughout as far as practicable.


20.18.3   All steel trunking and fittings shall be protected against corrosion.


20.18.4   The steel trunking installation shall be made mechanically and electrically
          continuous throughout,and be effectively earthed.


20.18.5   Electrical continuity shall be achieved by means of connecting a protective
          conductor of adequate size across the two adjacent ends of the trunking.


20.18.6   Every entry to the trunking installation shall be provided with smooth bore
          bushes or grommets and the return edge of the lid of the trunking shall be left
          intact in order to prevent and/or to be protected against the ingress of water.


20.19 Ducting
20.19.1   Ducts shall be sealed all round, including any removable lids or covers,
          against ingress of moisture and dirt.

20.19.2   Lids shall be provided to enable the cables to be introduced easily into the
          duct.


20.19.3   The cables and cable loom shall be cleated or otherwise secured into the duct
          sufficiently frequently to prevent movement.


20.19.4   Ducting with top access lids shall be avoided whenever possible and will not
          be accepted for under floor mounting.


20.19.5   Duct lids shall not be used for cable support.


20.20 Space Factor
          Space factor of at least 45% shall be provided for all cable conduits, trunkings
          and ductings.

Section 20, page 20-36



20.21 Cable Runs
20.21.1   All cables shall be run in a vertical or horizontal direction, where practicable
          and shall be secured flat or in a bundle, such as on the surface of body panels,
          columns, partitions or ceilings, throughout the entire route.


20.21.2   Where cables run as a span, such as between beams, trusses, rigid support
          throughout their entire length shall be used.


20.21.3   Cables crossing an expansion joint shall be formed into a loop such that any
          movement in the joint shall not stress the cables.


20.21.4   Where a wiring system passes through elements of car construction such as
          floors, walls and roofs, the opening remaining after passage of the wiring
          system shall be sealed according to the specified degree of fire resistance.

20.21.5   The internal bending radii of all cables shall not exceed the limit provided by
          the associated cable manufacturers.


20.21.6   All exterior cables external to equipment cases or ducts that are smaller than 6
          AWG must be protected by conduits, trunking or ducts. Interior cables shall
          be appropriately supported in conduits, trunking, trays, ducts or free-air.

20.21.7   Heavy Current Connections


   (a)    Heavy current connections may be by cable or bare strip.


   (b)    Heavy current cables run in ducts or unprotected shall be adequately cleated
          or secured against chafing or movement. Unprotected power cables, suitably
          sheathed, shall be cleated at not more than 400 mm centres. For the smaller
          cable size cleat distances less than this may be necessary. Such cables may be
          run bundled together as necessary to give additional support.


   (c)    Cable runs shall not cross a horizontal floor or surface except where
          unavoidable, and then a clearance of at least 25 mm shall be left beneath the
          cables, and where the likelihood exists of the cables being damaged they shall

be protected by a removable tread plate.


(d)     Bare copper strip may be used within enclosures, with the following
        provisions:


( i )   The conductor shall be of adequate stiffness, and shall be adequately
        supported and clamped against movement, resonance or vibrations.


(ii) Adjacent conductors may be separated by an insulator to ensure correct
        spacing and to give increased stiffness.

Section 20, page 20-37



   (iii)   The arrangements shall be such that no stress is placed on the terminations by
           the conductors.



   (iv)    All bends radii shall be appropriate to the hardness of the copper strip used.
   (e)     Where cables pass through holes in the traction motor frame, oil resistant
           resilient bushes suitably clamped shall be provided to prevent chafing of
           cables and to seal against the ingress of oil and water.


20.21.8    Light Current Connections


   (a)     Light current connections outside enclosures shall be by cables protected by
           conduits or ducts, or unprotected where so approved.


   (b)     Cables inside enclosures may be run unprotected, and, where more than one
           cable, made up into cable looms.


   (c)     Cable looms shall be made up by fastening them together to form a neat
           bundle. The individual cables shall be laid parallel and pulled straight and
           shall have a neat appearance. Particular care to obtain parallel lays shall be
           taken where looms go round corners.


   (d)     The looms shall be fastened at not more than 150 mm intervals. Fastenings
           shall also be applied at the start and finish of any bend, and at the point at
           which one or more cables leave the loom so as to secure the leaving cables.
           The term fastening includes the application of flame retardant lacing cord or
           of approved, non metallic, proprietary fasteners to secure the bundle. The use
           of self adhesive tape or lacing cord will not be accepted. Care shall be taken
           that the fastenings are not tightened excessively. Fastenings shall only be
           applied using the manufacturers recommended tool to obtain the tightening
           force appropriate to the cable.


   (e)     As far as practicable cables shall leave looms at right angles, to give a neat
           appearance. Sufficient slack shall be allowed to prevent a constraint being
           placed on cable terminations.

(f)   The use of proprietary cable ducting and support systems inside enclosures as
      an alternative to the foregoing requirements shall be submitted for approval.


(g)   High and low voltage cables shall be kept separate. Where cables of greater
      than 208 V between conductors are approved as being carried in the same
      jumper as other cables they may be run together as far as the adjacent junction
      box. AC cables shall not be run so as to result in eddy current heating of
      conduits.

Section 20, page 20-38



   (h)     Light current cables or cable looms shall be adequately secured to supports.
           Cables or cable looms shall be supported sufficiently frequently to prevent
           movement chafing or vibration in service.


20.21.9    Location of Cables and Looms


   (a)    Cables and looms shall be run in such positions that they are clear of
          apparatus and do not impede access for maintenance. They shall be clear of
          high temperature and electric arc areas. Arc or heat barriers to protect the
          cable runs shall be provided where it is not possible to avoid such areas, in
          such a way as to allow circulation of air around the cables.


   (b)    Sharp edges over or near which cables or looms may run shall be protected.
          The possibility of displacement in service shall be duly considered. Where
          cables pass through metallic partitions polychloroprene grommets or
          equivalent protection shall be provided.

20.21.10 Cable Identification


   (a)    All wires shall be indelibly marked for proper circuit idenfication. Where the
          wires are confined within a particular component, colour coding may be used.

   (b)    Each wire #10 AWG and similar shall be permanently and legibly marked
          along its entire length by means of hot stamping or equivalent. Each
          designation shall be no more than 3-inches from the last designation on the
          last 24-inches of wire nearest the termination, and 36-inches apart on the rest
          of the wire run. The circuit designation shall reflect what is shown on the
          electrical schematics.

   (c)    Wires larger than #10 AWG, multi-conductor cables, and other wires not
          capable of being continuously stamped, shall be identified by white or yellow
          heat shrinkable wire sleeves, attached to each end of the wire. The sleeve shall
          be printed with the circuit designation, and installed on the end of the wire as
          close to the termination as practical.


   (d)    Wire sleeves shall be of a type that does not come loose, age nor deteriorate
          due to UV light, dirt, grease or contact with other contaminants which may be
          encountered in a railway environment. Neoprene rubber markers will not be
          accepted. Markers requiring dilating fluid will not be accepted. Samples shall
          be submitted to the Engineer for approval.

20.21.11   Conduit Runs


           Conduit shall be adequately secured and supported by clips or otherwise.
           Welding of conduit will not be accepted. Metallic conduit shall be used on
           trucks, in exposed positions on the underframe, and to protect the cables

Section 20, page 20-39



          between the Collector Shoe and protective devices for the traction and
          auxiliary supplies. Non metallic conduit shall be used elsewhere except as
          approved.


20.22 Safety Circuits
20.22.1   Insofar as is practicable safety circuits shall be run direct to apparatus and not
          to terminal bars. Where it is essential that intermediate terminals be used, (for
          example, circuits which pass through intercar jumpers) the terminals shall be
          covered and separated from others terminals. All safety circuit cables shall be
          coloured yellow.


20.22.2   The Engineer will direct which circuits or sub-circuits shall be designated
          safety circuits within the meaning of this Clause.


20.23 Inter-car Connections
20.23.1   Inter-car connection shall be by an approved form of multicore cable taken to
          contact boxes integral with the couplers.


20.23.2   600V connections shall be by bolted cables.



20.23.3   Care shall be taken that the cables run in easy bends without undue flexing.
20.24 Train Wires
          All multicore train wires shall be run from coupler to coupler, irrespective of
          whether required by the circuit, except where the circuits demand otherwise.


20.25 Spare Wires
20.25.1   Spare wires shall be provided and terminated in the same way as other wires.


20.25.2   The spare wires shall be shown on the wiring diagram and labelled with cable
          markers in the same way as all other wires.

20.25.3   As a minimum requirement, the following spare control hardwires shall be
          provided for future uses:


   (a)    Between the electrical connection boxes of the auto-couplers: all remaining
          electrical connections shall be provided with spare wires.


   ( b ) Between underframe connection boxes at car ends: 6 nos. of spare wires shall
         be provided.


   ( c ) Between underframe connection boxes and equipment cases: 4 nos. of spare
         wires shall be provided.

Section 20, page 20-40



   ( d ) Connection boxes between underframe and saloon: 6 nos. of spare wires shall
         be provided.


   ( e ) Between saloon connection boxes and equipment inside the saloon: 4 nos. of
         spare wires shall be provided.


20.25.4   All spare wires shall be properly secured and insulated by appropriate end cap
          or capsulate.


20.26. Insulators and Insulating Panels and Boards
20.26.1   All insulating material used for the train shall be non-hygroscopic, anit-
          tracking and substantially non-ignitable. Phenolic resin bonded paper to BS
          5102 (if not applicable, replacement by BS EN 60893-2-2004 is acceptable) or
          phenolic resin bonded fabric to BS 2966 Type 2A, shall be used for panels or
          for small insulators of simple shape.


20.26.2   All surfaces of insulators or insulating panels shall be smooth, hard, free from
          air bubbles, cracks, scratches, inclusions or similar surface imperfections.


20.26.3   Moulded resin insulators for areas where arcs are present, including brush
          gear support insulators, shall be moulded of a suitable grade of silica filled
          epoxy resin, or similar approved material so formulated that, in the event of a
          flashover, the insulator can be cleaned and fit for further service by wiping or,
          in severe cases by minimal cleaning with aluminium oxide paper.


20.26.4   The insulators shall have a smooth finish without special surface coating.


20.26.5   Brush gear support insulators shall be fitted with a PTFE replaceable sleeve.


20.26.6   Ceramic insulators shall only be used where approved, and approval will only
          be granted where alternative materials cannot be used.

20.26.7   Moulded mica tubes or components of similar materials shall not be used.
20.27.Circuits and Earthing
20.27     General


20.27.1   This Clause covers all car electrical circuits.
20.27.2   Simplicity is required in circuit design. The number of different types of
          component shall be minimised.


20.27.3   Unless specifically approved by the Engineer, DC and single phase AC
          circuits shall be such that one pole of each device shall be connected directly
          to the negative or neutral line, without switches, fuses or contacts on the
          negative side.

Section 20, page 20-41




20.27.4   The practice of de energising devices by short circuiting the operating coil
          will not be permitted. The use of economy resistors or of separate pull in and
          hold coils for contactors, solenoids or similar devices will not be accepted.


20.28 600V Traction Circuits


20.28.1   600V traction circuits shall be protected by overload and/or current balance
          relays operating approved fault rupturing devices. Fuses will not be accepted.
          A high speed fault limiting device shall be provided. The device shall meet the
          requirements of IEC 60077. Collector Shoes, lightning arrestors (if provided),
          and lead in cables may be regarded as protected by the sub station system.


20.28.2   600V Auxiliary Circuits


          600V auxiliary circuits shall be protected by fuses. In all cases, the fault
          discriminating characteristics of the system shall be submitted for approval.


20.28.3   Low Voltage Circuits


   (a)    DC power sources shall be protected on the input side where practicable. In
          the case of a battery, it shall be protected by fuses in both the positive and
          negative lines installed in close proximity to the respective battery terminals.
          The unprotected positive and negative battery cables and terminals shall be
          physically segregated.


   (b)    Battery switches shall be provided.


   (c)    AC power sources shall have a fuse or miniature circuit breakers (MCB) in
          each phase and the neutral shall be earthed.
                                                  2



   (d)    Fuses, except as mentioned above, shall only be used where approved.

(e)   Protection and isolation of low voltage circuits other than the above shall be
        by MCB. Note that in all cases, these will be backed up by the power source
        fuses.


  (f)   Where regular switching is anticipated, separate switches shall be provided in
        addition to the MCBs.



20.29 Cable Ratings
        Rating of cables of 4.0 mm2 or larger shall not be less than 90% of the rating
        of the protecting fuse or MCB. 2.5 mm cable may be protected by an MCB of

Section 20, page 20-42
                                       2




          up to 30 A rating and 1 mm cable may be protected by an MCB of up to 20 A
          rating.



20.30 Earthing
20.30.1   Separate insulated earthing bars shall be provided for the 600VDC, 37.5VDC
          and 360VAC circuits.


20.30.2   Earthing bars for 600V circuits shall be connected to at least two earthing
          brush boxes on different trucks by separate cables.


20.30.3   Car bodies shall be earthed to at least two other earthing brush boxes also on
          different trucks.


20.30.4   Traction motor frames shall be connected to the adjacent earthing brush box in
          all cases. The same earthing brush boxes shall not be used for the 600V circuit
          and for the car body earths.


20.30.5   Earthing brush boxes shall be insulated from their mountings for 750V and
          arranged so that build up of dirt cannot short circuit the insulation. Care shall
          be taken that earth paths in parallel to the earth brushes via bearings are
          prevented.


20.30.6   The Collector Shoe lead conduit construction and earthing shall provide a low
          impedance path to any likely fault current. The conduit(s) shall be of heavy
          gauge weather proof construction and be adequately earthed to the underframe
          by an earthing bar used solely for this purpose. Proper sealing shall be
          provided to protect the conduit entry against the ingress of water.


20.30.7   Low voltage earthing bars shall be connected directly to the car body by a
          bolted link.

20.30.8    The negative or neutral of each separate AC or DC circuit including power
           sources shall be connected separately to the earthing bar of the car in which is
           the appropriate power source. For the purposes of this Clause, the negative of
           each circuit supplied by a separate MCB shall be considered a separate circuit.


20.30.9    In the case of train line negative the connection shall be in the operative cab
           made by a suitable contactor.


20.30.10   Resiliently mounted equipment shall be provided with earth links.


20.30.11   Such as all equipment cases and resistor frames, mountings on the underframe
           must be properly earthed by an earthing cable connected to a earthing pad on
           the underframe.

Section 20, page 20-43



20.30.12   Where equipment with secondary or tertiary insulation systems are used, all
           live and floating conductors shall be protected by an earthed cover.


20.30.13   The negative or neutral of each separate AC or DC circuit including power
           sources shall be connected separately to the corresponding earthing bar of the
           car in which the power source originates. For the purposes of this Clause, a
           separate circuit shall be considered to be that circuit that is supplied by an
           individual MCB.


20.30.14   In the case of the train line negative the connection shall only be made at one
           point. This shall be achieved in the car of the active driving cab via the use of
           a suitably rated contactor.


20.30.15 All metallic boxes, cases and enclosures containing electrical equipment,
           including cable ducts, which are not intended to be part of the live circuit shall
           be properly earthed with an insulated flexible earth bond to the relevant earth
           bar.


20.30.16   Earthing by means of a flexible earth bond shall be required on each
           equipment case irrespective of whether the equipment case is directly
           mounted to the car body.


20.30.17   For auxiliary voltage circuits designed with earth returns within the metallic
           equipment case these shall be connected to a common, insulated earthing
           terminal bar which shall be connected to the appropriate earthing bar by a
           flexible earth bond.
           Item 20.30.17: (No specifications text modifications required.)




20.30.18   Where the metallic equipment case is constructed of a ferrous metal the earth
           terminal shall be welded to the casing.


20.30.19   Non-ferrous metallic equipment cases shall also require a permanently fixed

earthing terminal mounted in a way to ensure that any electrolytic action is
           prevented.


20.30.20   Both earthing terminals and the flexible earth bonds shall be suitably sized to
           accommodate the prospective fault current, also taking into account the
           relevant fault detection/isolation system.


20.30.21   The physical length of the flexible earth bond shall be as small as practically
           possible and its purpose shall be clearly distinguishable.


20.30.22   Detachment of either end of the flexible bond shall be such that it does not fall
           into any moving parts or on to any electrical item that may be live.

Section 20, page 20-44



20.30.23   The position of the earth terminal/stud assemblies and the associated earthing
           cables shall enable the termination to be easily connected without the
           requirement to remove any equipment or apparatus.


20.30.24   All earth terminations shall be clearly visible.


20.30.25   An associated group of electrical components, from a common power source,
           not within an equipment casing shall be suitably earthed at one common point.


20.30.26   Loop earthing between items of equipment is not acceptable.


20.30.27   Where equipment with secondary or tertiary insulation systems are used, all
           live and floating conductors shall be protected by an earthed cover.


20.30.28   In the event of non-metallic boxes, cases and enclosures being used there shall
           be no metallic fastenings passing from the inside to the outside which can be
           inadvertently energised electrically by a fault occurring inside the box, case or
           enclosure.


20.30.29   The cross sectional area of the earthing cable shall not be less than that of the
           incoming supply to the case or frame.


20.30.30   Any earth fault or insulation breakdown shall not cause any object accessible
           to maintenance or operating staff to become live.


20.30.31   The removal of any earthed equipment or item shall not interrupt the earthing
           arrangement of any other remaining earthed electrical equipment.


20.30.32   Special earthing arrangements for electronic equipment where required, shall
           be submitted for approval, and shall be compatible with the above.

20.30.33   Screens shall be provided on circuits to meet the requirements of the
           equipment or system concerned.


20.30.34   The screen shall be continuous through all intermediate
           connections/components on a car.


20.30.35   Screen earths and low auxiliary earths shall not be terminated on the same
           terminal.


20. 30.36 The screen shall not form a path for circulating currents.


20.31 Circuit Diagrams
           Circuit diagrams shall be clear and easy to interpret and shall comply with
           IEEE Std 315.

Section 20, page 20-45



20.32.Auxiliary Contacts
20.32.1   Auxiliary contacts shall be of the silver butt type. They shall be contained in a
          separate dust proof contact enclosure under an approved type of cover. In the
          case of small relays and the like the whole relay may be contained in the
          enclosure. The contact enclosure is required irrespective of the type of
          enclosure of the main equipment. The cover shall be transparent plastic and all
          fixings shall be captive. Acrylic resin will not be accepted.


20.32.2   The Engineer shall be satisfied that condensation of moisture inside the
          contact enclosure will be prevented. Contacts shall be adequately protected
          against corrosion.


20.32.3   The above requirements also apply to the contact section of master controllers,
          but the enclosure may be formed by the controller case and need not be of
          transparent plastic.


20.32.4   The connections shall be made outside the contact enclosure. It shall be
          possible, as far as practicable, to remove a contact enclosure complete and
          substitute another of the same type without removing the contact cover.


20.32.5   Notwithstanding the above, the use of an approved type of small contactor for
          several applications, either as a relay or as a contactor, shall be considered,
          even if it does not fully comply with the foregoing, to economise on
          equipment types.



20.33. Power Contacts
20.33.1   All power contacts shall be fitted with contact tips, securely fixed to their
          support and arranged for easy removal without further dismantling. Contact
          screws of size M8 or larger shall not be provided with screwdriver slots.
          Current shall be taken from moving contacts by flexible copper braids, amply
          proportioned and having end connections secured by crimping only, with
          flared ends to avoid abrasion of the shunt. Braids shall be supported and
          restrained so as to prevent damage due to excessive movement or vibration.
          Passage of current through springs or bearings shall be positively prevented.

20.33.2   Fixings of all blowout coils and connections shall be submitted for approval.
          Blowout coils shall be connected on the positive side of the contacts.
          Permanent magnet blowouts shall be submitted for approval.


20.33.3   Arc horns which are removed with the arc chute are not permitted. Where
          used, the associated flexible lead shall be sleeved.

Section 20, page 20-46



20.33.4   The Contractor shall satisfy the Engineer that all arc chute components have
          adequate resistance to erosion and burning from the arcs to which they may be
          subjected.


20.33.5   Arc chutes shall be of a manageable size. Arc chutes that weigh more than 5
          kg shall include an inner replaceable arc box to avoid changing the whole
          assembly when cheek wear occurs.


20.34 Rotating Electrical Machines
20.34.1   The design of all rotating electrical machines used for the train shall be
          complied with IEC 60349.


20.34.2   All rotating electrical machines, particularly those are underfloor mounted,
          shall be fitted with resilient mountings to eliminate transmission of
          mechanical vibrations to the carbody.


20.34.3   Rotating parts shall also be adequately guarded and protected against ejection
          under failure conditions. Suitable protection shall be put in place to guard
          against the ejection of rotating parts under failure conditions.


20.34.4   The rotating electrical machines shall be of the self ventilated type, with
          simple means provided for exclusion of dust and water. Alternatively, fully
          enclosed proven air cooled type motor will be considered.


20.35 Coils and Windings
20.35.1   This Clause shall apply to all coils and windings, including relay and
          contactor coils, inductances and transformers, but excluding coils and
          windings for machines or for oil immersed equipment.


20.35.2   All coils shall be fully impregnated, or encapsulated by a system rated class H,
          and shall be continuously rated at the maximum working voltage and/or
          current, except where approved.

20.35.3   Connections to coils shall be to terminals securely fixed to the coil body, to
          which the ends of the winding can be brought, and which can carry a suitable
          fixing for the incoming lead.


20.35.4   Coils with leads which are brought out from the coil shall be submitted for
          approval. The leads shall be of suitably insulated multistrand wire and taken to
          an adjacent terminal block or connector. The joint between the winding and
          the lead shall be taped or otherwise fixed into the coil body.


20.35.5   All coils shall be securely fixed to their cores, or otherwise arranged to
          prevent movement in service.

Section 20, page 20-47



20.36 Plugs and Plug in Components
          All multipin plugs, plug in relays, component boards, electronic cards or racks,
          or the like shall comply with the following:


20.36.1   The plug or device shall be adequately and positively secured against working
          loose.


20.36.2   The plug contacts shall be adequate and proof against failure to make good
                                          2
          contact.


20.36.3   Incorrect insertion of the plug or device and consequent damage to the contact
          shall be positively prevented by the use of a guide, shield, or otherwise.


20.36.4   The cable shall be attached to the plug or socket by an approved method.
          Where the cable size is 1.0 mm or larger crimped connection shall be used
          except where otherwise approved.


20.36.5   All the plugs and sockets shall be labelled.


20.36.6   The caps shall be provided to cover equipment sockets when removed from
          the car.



20.37 Control Relays and Contactors
20.37.1   Unless electrical isolation is required for safety reason or otherwise specified,
          control relay shall not be used and microprocessor or software based
          equipment shall be used whereas applicable (refer to PS 20.50).


20.37.2   Calibrated relays shall have the adjusting mechanism securely locked after
          setting. Calibration marking on the relays will not be required.

20.37.3   Where the use of time delay relays is accepted they shall not use liquid
          damping to obtain the time delay unless the damper is of the fully sealed type.


20.37.4   Microswitches of the fully sealed type will be considered subject to
          satisfactory performance on an endurance test, as part of a contactor or
          otherwise.


20.38 Low Voltage Components
20.38.1   Low voltage components such as all low voltage switches, rotary switches and
          push buttons indicator lamps shall be submitted for approval.


20.38.2   The size, colour and brightness of fault indicator and similar lights shall be
          submitted for approval. If filament lamps are used the lamp bulbs shall be

Section 20, page 20-48



          underrun by energising them at less than 90% of their rated voltage. If
          required, filament lamps shall use dim/bright indication.


20.38.3   Low Voltage toggle switches shall have a quick action mechanism. Switch
          contacts shall be of the wiper or wiping butt type. Alternatively the use of
          switches or push buttons with the whole contact part mounted in a sealed box,
          will be considered. Toggle switches shall have the "Off" position upwards (2
          position type) or in the mid position (3 position type) except where otherwise
          approved.


20.38.4   Rotary switches shall have a quick action mechanism and shall be capable of
          continuous rotation in either direction. They shall have a steel shaft not less
          than 9 mm at the least section. Except where otherwise specified they shall
          have the position for normal service with the operating handle vertical.


20.38.5   Push buttons, except where otherwise specified, shall be shrouded.


20.39 Protection Devices
20.39.1   Miniature circuit breakers (MCBs) shall be of the magnetically tripped type in
          accordance with IEC 60934. The OFF and Tripped position shall be the same,
          with toggle downwards. Alternative circuit breaker type shall be submitted for
          approval.
20.39.2   The toggle shall be arranged to include means to attach securely, a label or a
          seal, but tripping of the device shall not be inhibited by such a seal. Operation
          of the tripping mechanism shall return the toggle to the OFF position. MCBs
          having alternative arrangements shall not be offered.


20.39.3   The MCB's offered shall be available in the combinations set out in IEC
          60934, incorporating trip for coils remote operation, auxiliary contacts rated at
          not less than 0.5 A, 37.5 VDC., alternative breaker current/time tripping
          characteristics and with minimum trip currents between 101 % and 125 % of
          the rated current. The load rating calculations for each MCB shall be
          submitted for approval. The calculation shall be revised based on loads
          measured on the cars, and MCB ratings amended as necessary.

20.39.4   Particular care shall be taken to ensure adequate creepage distances to earth
          and between terminals of adjacent MCBs are maintained with the units
          grouped as closely as possible.


20.39.5   MCBs shall be mounted in such a way that shrinkage of insulating panels does
          not cause loosening of the electrical connections.


20.39.6   Access shall be provided to the rear of the insulating panel, which may be
          hinged for this purpose where so approved. Where mounted on a switch board
          in a cab or similar positions a front sheet metal cover shall be provided, so

Section 20, page 20-49



          arranged that any one MCB can be removed from the front without disturbing
          the rest, after removal of an escutcheon plate or otherwise.


20.39.7   Irrespective of the toggle position, the upper connection to all MCBs shall be
          the line (AC circuits) or the positive (DC circuits).


20.40 Fuses
          All fuses shall comply with IEC 60269-1. Fuse carriers shall be back inserted,
          provision being made to remove the complete fuse panel.


20.41 High current Resistors
20.41.1   Heavy current resistance elements shall comply with IEC 60322 and shall be
          of the edgewound corrosion resistant, unbreakable "non sag" type. Such
          resistors shall have a negligible temperature coefficient.


20.41.2   High voltage heavy current resistor elements shall be mounted on, and
          insulated from (primary insulation) a steel sub frame and the sub frame itself
          shall be mounted on and insulated from (secondary insulation) the main
          resistance frame. All insulation shall be suitable for the system voltage. Care
          shall be taken that adequate strength and insulation is provided at the support
          for the sub frame. Mica tubes, as part of insulator assembles, will not be
          accepted.


20.41.3   All power resistor frames must be safety-earthed.


20.42 Light Current Resistors
20.42.1   Light current resistors shall be of the wire or strip wound type, with the
          conductor set in vitreous enamel. Where the wire size exceeds l mm the use of
          vitreous enamel is not mandatory but in all cases the coating, if any, shall not
          tend to peel off or disintegrate.


20.42.2   The sliders of pre set resistors shall be adequately locked in position. If
          adjustment is required between overhauls then the use of rotary preset

resistors is a requirement. Such resistors shall have a means of preventing
          casual adjustment of the setting.


20.42.3   Resistors shall have a resistance within ±5% of the nominal value, unless
          otherwise specified or approved. The value, rating and tolerance shall be
          marked on the resistor.


20.42.4   Carbon rod, or carbon track resistors will not be accepted. Silicon carbide
          resistors will not be permitted unless the Engineer is satisfied that they are
          adequately rated.

Section 20, page 20-50



20.42.5   High voltage protective resistances shall have a rating to match the
          characteristic of the protective fuse or other device and shall be subject to
          approval.



20.43 Capacitors
20.43.1   The type of capacitor used for each application shall be submitted for approval.
          The service life of electrolytic capacitors shall be at least 10 years.


20.43.2   Fuses and discharge resistors where required, shall not be integrated with the
          capacitors.

20.45.2   Instrument cases shall be weather proof, and of rugged construction. Small

20.49 Printed Circuit Board (PCB)


20.49.1   Material

(a)       The material for the PCB shall be:


( i )     high impact resisting,
( i i )     non-absorbent,
( i i i )    anti-corrosive,
( i v )     flame retardant,
( v )     ozone and Ultra-violet resisting, and
( v i )     produce low smoke and nil toxic fume such as carbon monoxide in the

(b)       The copper laminate shall be firmly attached to the board and shall be
          resistant to blistering and peeling when heated with a soldering iron.

Section 20, page 20-53




   (c)    The minimum thickness of PCB shall be at least 1.6mm.


20.49.2   The laminate used shall be epoxy-glass based to BS 4584 part 3 or CEM
          equivalent type (if not applicable, replacement by BS EN 60249-2-5-1994 is
          acceptable).



20.49.3   The board which is designed for free of maintenance, shall be potted by
          Epoxy. The potting material shall be of UL94V-0 rated.


20.49.4   Track Layout and Artwork


   (a)    Track to track, track to pad, and pad to pad spacing shall in general be as wide
          as the electrical clearance can allow.


   (b)    The cross-section of each circuit track shall be adequate to prevent fusing or
          delamination of the track under fault conditions before the protecting device,
          such as, fuse, has been able to interrupt the fault current.


20.49.5   Component Layout and Fixing

   (a)    Component parts shall be located, secured and disposed with respect to each
          other and the structure members so that they can be inspected, removed and
          replaced without damage to or causing an undue disturbance of other parts or
          wiring.


   (b)    All components shall be mounted such that they do not become damaged or
          disconnected when the equipment is subjected to any type and routine tests.

   (c)    All components shall be mounted on one side only.


   (d)    Physical separation and protection of the terminals and wiring shall be
          provided by means of insulation separators.

20.49.6   Protective Coatings

(a)    All PCB assemblies shall be protected on both sides with a flame retardant
          protective transparent coating, in order to prevent deterioration or corrosion
          due to moisture and atmospheric contaminants. The coating shall not have any
          adverse reaction with any other materials or components used. The coating
          shall be solvent removable with cleaner for PCB repairing purpose.

   (b)    The type of coating and cleaner shall be submitted for approval.


20.49.7   Components

           All components shall comply with BS 9000.


20.49.8    Sourcing


   (a)     Components with complete physical and functional compatibility according to

   (b)     All integrated circuits and semi-conductor device shall be standard devices
           available from at least two different manufacturers.


20.49.9    Choke and Transformer


           The chokes and transformers listed in the component list are the special
           purpose devices which shall be supplied by the Contractor. Windings shall be

           information and demonstrate operational compatibility.


20.49.10   Component Cooling


   (a)     All power electronic switches and heat dissipated components shall be of
           natural cooling type.


   (b)     Cooling fans shall not be used within electronic equipment unless a positive
           indication of fan failure is provided for maintenance purpose and subject to
           Appoval.


20.49.11   Push Button Switches


   (a)     Push button switches shall suit the standard 32.5 mm diameter panel hole
           fixing.

( b ) The contacts shall be rated for a life of not less that 10 years and shall be
         capable of operating under emergency conditions of multiple unit operation.


   ( c ) Terminals shall accept ring tongue crimps. The push button design shall be
         capable of assembly with at least 3 normally open plus one normally closed
         contacts.


   ( d ) The contract rating shall not be less than 2 A inductive with a time constant of
         15ms at 37.5 VDC.


20.49.12   Connectors


   (a)     All PCBs shall be connected to the internal case or rack wiring as appropriate

Section 20, page 20-55



           by means of approved multipin connectors. Connectors complied with DIN
           41612 and IEC 60603-2 shall be used.


   ( b ) Connectors between PCBs or electronic modules and the train wiring and/or
         other racks or cases shall be by means of multipole connectors.
   ( c ) Unless otherwise approved, the use of PCB edge connectors will not be
         permitted.


   ( d ) The contact area of each connector shall be plated with to a minimum
         thickness of 1.25µm of gold over a minimum of 0.75µm of low stress nickel.


   ( e ) Mechanical polarisation to prevent insertion into the wrong socket shall be

20.49.13   Locking


           Each PCB or module shall be positively retained in the rack or case by a
           fastener or spring loaded locking pin.


20.49.14   Limitation of failure


           In any electronic rack system, the failure of any one module or individual
           circuit board shall neither cause loss of the electronics power supply within
           the rack, nor cause subsequent failure of circuits on other PCBs or modules.


20.49.15   Status monitoring


           Each PCB or module shall incorporate indicator and/or test socket mounted on

   (a)     power supply on;


   (b)     status of digital inputs/outputs; and

(c)     status of analogue inputs/outputs.


20.49.16   Test points


   (a)     Test points shall be provided in an appropriate locations on modules and
           PCBs. A negative return test point shall be provided.


   (b)     The test points shall accept a standard 2mm diameter plug and shall be sited
           with sufficient clearance to permit a standard oscilloscope probe to be

   (c)     As an alternative, these test points may be wired through a connector to a

Section 20, page 20-56



          portable test and monitor box.


   (d)    Whichever method is used, each test point shall be clearly identified on both
          the equipment and on any related drawings.


20.50 Use of Microprocessor or Software Based Equipment
20.50.1   Single microprocessors shall not be used in circumstances where a single fault
          condition could result in any unsafe conditions. Where microprocessor based
          equipment is used in a safety application, a minimum of three independent
          processor shall be used, with any output recurring a minimum 2 out of 3 vote
          before being activated.


20.50.2   Where microprocessor system incorporate technology such as surface
          mounted component, multilayer circuit boards or flexible PCBs, the
          Contractor shall provide evidence demonstrating that satisfactory operational
          experience has been gained on the successful use of these technologies in a
          similar railway environment.


20.50.3   It is preferred that Integrated Circuits (ICs) are soldered directly into the
          circuit board. This includes all forms of memory IC and microprocessors. The
          use of sockets in specific instances will be considered at the discretion of the
          Engineer and will generally be limited to the installation of preprogrammed
          devices containing the operating software for the system. Where IC sockets
          are employed, the devices contained therein shall be positive retained once
          installed.


20.50.4   Microprocessor based system shall have watchdog circuits to ensure correct
          software operation. The watchdog circuit should not be reset except when the
          main control program, including all subroutines and allied programs, is
          running correctly. When the watchdog circuit detects a fault, it shall trigger
          hardware forcing all system outputs into a safe state before resetting the
          system and then the system shall enter into a self-test mode. Normal operation
          shall only be resumed if all self-test checks are satisfactory.


20.50.5   Power supply rails shall be closely monitored. Any transient or dip likely to
          cause data corruption, or partial loss of correct hardware initialisation states,

shall be detected and outputs forced into a safe state. When the power supply
          recovers , all ICs shall be reset and the system re-initialised.


20.50.6   Microprocessor systems shall incorporate self-test and diagnostic facilities to
          locate and indicate faults within the system. It is preferred that the system has
          sufficient inbuilt diagnostic capabilities to automatically identify all system
          faults. However, any additional in-built test hardware or software shall not
          lead to reduced system reliability or safety. It shall also be possible to use

Section 20, page 20-57



           such diagnostic facilitates whilst the equipment is in normal operation in order
           that real-time events may be monitored whilst the train is in motion.


20.50.7    Design consideration shall be given to the diagnostic facilitates to record
           system behaviour and parameters for a period before and after a trigger signal
           initiated from the diagnostics terminal for maintenance purpose.


20.50.8    Where microprocessor systems require additional test or diagnostic equipment,
           this shall be portable for use on the train. It shall wherever possible derive its
           power supply from that of the system under test. Where the test/diagnostic
           equipment employs portable computers, the Contractor shall provide means of
           powering such equipment from the low voltage power supply of the train.


20.50.9    Test equipment shall be robust and easy to use with the minimum of specialist
           training.


20.50.10   Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) shall be used to indicate faulty modules to
           allow rapid fault diagnosis and maintenance.


20.50.11   Faults occurring during system operation shall be logged with information
           stored in non-volatile memory. The data stored shall be accessed by a portable
           hand-held terminal for maintenance purposes, shall be concise and allow the
           nature of the fault to be clearly identified. The hand-held terminal shall also be
           used to access or control any in-built system maintenance functions such as
           signal state monitoring and control of output signals for test purposes.


20.50.12   For those software functions that are operational related, the software shall be
           designed in such a manner that it shall be possible to access and adjust within
           safe limits the operating parameters of the equipment for test and development
           purpose without modifying the source code. Choices for “save” or “remove”
           the change shall be provided at the end of the adjustment process of the
           operating parameters. Any alternations without “saving” the change shall be
           lost whenever the equipment is re-initialised. When a “saved” change is made,
           automatic update of the software parameter version shall be provided when
           the equipment is re-initialised. Security measure shall be provided in the

above adjustment process to prevent unauthorized alternation.


20.50.13   Microprocessor bus signals shall be properly terminated to prevent cross-talk
           or corruption of signals. Bus signals shall be well separated and ground planes
           used on PCBs to reduce susceptibility to electro-magnetic interference.


20.50.14   Additional requirements of the microprocessor based system on the
           application of TIMS shall refer to PS 10.

Section 20, page 20-58

20.51.1   The Contractor and his Subcontractors shall comply with the specified health

20.51.2   The Contractor and his Subcontractors will be required to stop work whenever

20.52 Paint Performance
20.52.1   All painted surfaces shall have a service life mutually established between the
          Paint Supplier, the Contactor and the AUTHORITY.


20.52.2   The paint coating shall resist mechanical damage in accordance with the
          following requirements for its specified life:


   (a)    Scratch resistance in accordance with BS 3900 : Part E2 : 1992 when using
          when using a 2.5 kg load.


   (b)    Impact resistance in accordance with BS 3900 : Part E7 : 1992.


   (c)    Clip resistance in accordance with BS AU 148 : Part 15 : 1990. The degree of
          damage shall not exceed Grade 2.


   (d)    Abrasion resistance equivalent to ASTM D4060 - 84, shall be such that the
          weight loss shall not exceed 30 mg after 500 cycles, using CS10 wheels
          detailed in the Taber Abrader Test.


20.52.3   Paint adhesion in accordance with BS 3900 : Part E6 : 1974 shall meet level 1
          with 1 mm spacing between cross cuts.

20.52.4   Paint elasticity for metal substrate, in accordance with the following parts of
          BS 3900, shall


   (a)    not exceed 25 mm when using the conical mandril defined in Part E11 : 1985.


   (b)    be greater than 3.5 mm under slow deformation, as defined in Part E4 : 1995.


20.52.5   The paint coating shall be capable of withstanding all contaminants
          encountered in normal service as well as the cleaning routines detailed in the
          PS.


20.52.6   The gloss level of the painted surface shall not fade by more than 10%
          throughout its service life in accordance with BS 3900 : Part D5 : 1997.

Section 20, page 20-59




20.52.7       The painted surface shall not exhibit any mottling, cracking, blistering or
              other forms of deterioration throughout its service life.


20.52.8       All painted surfaces shall match and display a uniformity of colour throughout
              their service life.

Section 21           Design Requirements

21.1      Purpose


21.1.1.   The policies and procedures presented in this Section establish a common
          frame of reference for developing the System Engineering Management
          System (SEMS).


21.1.2.   21.1.2.    The SEMS shall be an integral part of the Quality Management
          System (refer to PS 27) and shall also meet the requirement for Quality
          Assurance or Management in design in accordance with the ISO 9000: 2005.
          The general guidelines specified in the IEEE Std 1220-2005 “IEEE Standard
          for Application and Management of the Systems Engineering Process” shall
          be followed as far as applicable.


21.1.3.   These policies and procedures establish the basis for integrating the technical
          efforts of the entire design team of the Contractor to meet program, cost,
          schedule and performance objectives with an optimal design solution that
          encompasses the system and its associated manufacturing, test and support
          processes.


21.1.4.   The Contractor shall establish and maintain the SEMS in accordance with the
          policies and procedures.


21.2      Policies
21.2.1.   This Section of PS covers requirements of policies and procedures for the
          SEMS which shall be observed as the minimum requirements which are
          acceptable to the Engineer.


21.2.2.   The Contractor may offer alternative standards which are equivalent to or
          better than those herein, and which the Contractor shall justify to the
          satisfaction of the Engineer.

21.2.3.   The Contractor shall nominate a System Engineering Management (SEM)
          representative with overall responsibility for the SEMS. The SEMS shall be
          initiated by a series of design plans (refer to PS 21.2.6(b)) which shall identify
          and establish the required documents detailing policy, organizations,
          engineering tasks, processes and the necessary documentation to be prepared.


21.2.4.   The SEM shall be applied throughout the design life cycle as a comprehensive,
          iterative technical management process to:

21.5.1.   Goals and Objectives of Operability Plan

(a)    In order to facilitate the operability design development, an Operability Plan

( b ) The Operability Plan shall be submitted at each stage of SEMP to ensure the
      potential design solutions is able to meet the specified train service,
      operational, maintenance and training needs.


( c ) The goals of Operability Plan is to ensure a thorough understanding of the
      functional relationships between the operational safety and efficiency of
      operation and control system and the characteristics of the operator as a

          person, tasks, environments, and technologies; hence to apply the above
          understanding to:


(i)       Enhance system safety by integrating human performance characteristics and
          technological functions to anticipate (and minimize) the probability and
          adverse consequences of human or system errors;


(ii)      Optimize the efficiency of the operation and control system by explicitly
          assessing and accounting for the capabilities and limitations of the human
          component.


(d)       The objectives of Operability Plan are:


(i )      To develop increased knowledge and predictive models of human

( i i )    To develop human factor engineering design criteria based on the

          maintain the system.

21.5.9.   Human Engineering Design


          The design of train systems, equipment and facilities shall reflect human
          engineering factors that affect human performance, including, when
          applicable:


   (a)    Satisfactory atmospheric conditions including composition, pressure,
          temperature and humidity, including safeguards against uncontrolled
          variability beyond acceptable limits.

   (b)     Range of acoustic noise, vibration, acceleration, shock, blast, and impact
           forces and safeguards against uncontrolled variability beyond safe limits.


   (c)     Protection from thermal, mechanical, electrical, electromagnetic, visual, and

   (d)     Adequate space for personnel, their equipment, and free volume for the
           movements and activities they are required to perform during operation and

   (e)     Efficient arrangement of operation and maintenance workplace, equipment,

21.5.10.   Fail Safe Design


           A fail safe design shall be provided in those areas where failure can cause
           catastrophe through damage to equipment, injury to personnel or inadvertent
           operation of critical equipment.


21.5.11.   Simplicity of Design

The equipment shall represent the simplest design consistent with functional
           requirements and expected service conditions. It shall be capable of being
           operated, maintained, and repaired in its operational environment by personnel
           with a minimum of training.

           The design of the system shall reflect the interaction requirements of the
           TIMS (refer to PS 10).

performance and failure modes.


21.7.2.   EMC Standards


          The supplied equipment shall meet internationally recognized standards,
          where applicable, on EMC requirements. The EMC plan shall list the
          applicable standard to be adhered to in the areas of:


          (a) Susceptibility to Radiated Electromagnetic Energy

Section 21, page 21-20



             (b) Electrical Fast Transient/Burst


             (c) Electrostatic Discharge


             (e) Radiated, Radio-Frequency, Electromagnetic Field Immunity


             (f) Surge Immunity


             (h) Conducted Disturbances Immunity


             (i) Power Frequency Magnetic Field Immunity


21.7.3.      Interference Considerations


             The Contractor shall take into account the following interference mechanisms
             in his design and take all necessary measures to eliminate their impact on the
             supplied equipment:


   (a)       Radiated interference - at a distance greater than approximately one sixth of a
             wavelength away from a radiating antenna or interfering source the radiation
             field dominates and is the mechanism to be considered;


   (b)       Induced interference - can be due to direct magnetic induction from power
             electronics and cables. The induction field produced by rate of change of
             current not equal to zero is the most significant component at distances less
             than one sixth of a wavelength away from the disturbing source;


   (c)       Conducted interference - can take several forms:


   ( i )     Interference present on the power supply to equipment


   ( i i )    Equipment that shares a common earth return can be subjected to

interference from other equipment due to voltage drops across the return path


( i i i )   Signalling equipment that uses the running rails as conductors to transmit or
        receive signals is subject to interference coupled into the running rails as a
        result of traction return current in the running rails


(iv)    Equipment with external interface can be subjected to interference present on
        interface cables and wires


(d)     Electrostatic discharge - occurs under dry atmospheric conditions in which
        electrostatic discharge from the human body (can become charged to several
        thousand volts) can result in loss of data or may physically damage equipment
        containing sensitive components.

Section 21, page 21-21



   (e)    General Electromagnetic Interference


          The Contractor shall ensure that there is sufficient protection to prevent
          Electromagnetic Interference (EMI) from any components and systems of the
          supplied trainborne equipment, including traction motors and auxiliary
          converters, from affecting the on-board systems and systems within and
          adjacent to the Existing Lines.


21.7.4.   Rolling Stock Radiated and Conducted Emissions


          As a minimum requirement, the maximum levels of radiated EMI and
          conducted emission of trainborne equipment shall not exceed the levels
          specified in the Standard EN 50081-2.


21.7.5.   Rolling Stock Equipment Immunity Levels


   (a)    All trainborne electrical and electronic equipment shall be immune from any
          radiated electromagnetic interference produced by other pieces of trainborne
          equipment and external sources.


   (b)    Any equipment which contains sensitive electronic components to
          electrostatic discharge and is likely to be handled or touched by personnel or
          customers shall be protected against electrostatic discharge.


   (c)    All trainborne electrical and electronic equipment shall be immune to the
          conducted interference levels as defined in the Standard EN 50082-2 in the
          frequency range 150 kHz to 80 MHz.


21.7.6.   Communication Equipment Compatibility


   (a)    The communication equipment of the Existing Lines shall operate reliably in
          terms of performance and functionality in the electromagnetic environment

(b)   The Contractor shall liaise and co-operate with the Interfacing Contractors and
      Named Suppliers in the exchange of EMC data and related equipment

(c)   The Contractor shall limit levels of chopper/inverter harmonic currents/inrush
      current into trainborne filters and provide sufficient train input impedance to
      limit 600 Hz and 1200 Hz supply ripple currents.

      contractor will be immune to any magnetic fields generated by trains, third rail

21.8.5.   Method for Determining Audible Tones in Noise


          The method to determine the presence of pure tones shall be the tonality limits
          provided in Annex C of ISO/DIS 1996-2 Annex D. As an alternative, the
          Zwicker method can be used. This method is described in the following
          sections. As a minimum, the Zwicker method shall be provided for
          information.


   (a)    The method is based on the psycho-acoustic concept of critical bands and the
          objective of the method is to give the same judgement of the prominence of
          any tones as an average listener.


   (b)    The method is based on the Zwicker Critical Bands, and is in most details
          equivalent to ANSI S12.10:1985 (or ANSI S12.10:2002). It consists of three
          steps:

( i )     Frequency analysis.


( i i )    Determination of the sound pressure level of the tone(s) and the sound
          pressure level of the masking noise within a critical band centered at the tone
          frequency.


(iii)     The difference between the levels (∆Ltn) is compared to a criterion curve, and
          it is decided whether the tone is "Prominent".

           be Class I by examining whether the required performance would be impacted
           as a result of implementing the change.

       A Class II engineering change identifies a minor change to a Configuration
       Item or its documentation that can be affected entirely by the Contractor
       within the scope of the Contract effort without changing the approved
       Configuration Identification List. Class II changes are also applicable during
       production and are normally identified and processed to correct
       documentation errors or to enhance Contractor productivity without detriment
       to the Engineer.

Although the Engineering Change Proposal originator can be either the
      Engineer or the Contractor, all formal Engineering Change Proposal shall be
      prepared by the Contractor.

       concerned, and changes distributed with previous Specification Change Notice

          built in such a way that it satisfies the requirements of the Approved Design

          the Approved Design criteria have been met and the Routine Inspections
          ensure that the standard, Approved at First Article Inspection, is being
          maintained.

23.1 Scope of Training



23.1.1   The Contractor shall provide a comprehensive training program for the
         Commission's maintenance and operations employees. The program shall
         ensure that these employees have the competence to operate, maintain, and
         repair the subway cars to be supplied as part of this contract.


23.1.2   The maintenance training program shall be comprised of a series of instructor-
         led and computer-based training (CBT) modules whose content shall include
         but not necessarily be limited to all major vehicle systems and requisite
         procedures for operation, inspection, vehicle recovery, overhaul, and use of
         test equipment for each of these systems. For each module, the Contractor
         shall provide both instructor-led pilot and train-the-trainer sessions as well as
         training documentation.


23.1.3   The training documentation shall be sufficient to allow future on-going
         sustainable instruction by the Commission for its employees (refer to
         documentation requirements in Sections 23.2.1 and 23.3 below.)

         pilot and train-the-trainer sessions and adequately assessed the trainees’ skill

         subsequent training to Commission employees using the CBT modules. For
         the maintenance training and vehicle operation training programs, once the

Attachment C: Training Department Item Writing Guidelines
Item-Writing Guidelines for Multiple Choice Questions



Content


1 . Remember the guideline from SOP TR-001 Development of Written Tests: The
    content domain of written tests will normally contain only knowledge sections of
    the job analysis, performance sections that would be impractical to test on a
    performance test, and safety critical information.


2 . Use a content domain matrix to select content for questions.


3 . Focus the question on a single idea or task derived from a validated resource book
    or job analysis where available.


4 . Keep the question job-related and linked to a practical job competency possibly
    through creating a real-life scenario or situation in the stem of the question.


5 . Keep items independent. It should not be necessary to know the answer to one item
    to answer another; one item should not provide a clue to another.
Level of Difficulty


6.   Eliminate irrelevant difficulty by:


       • Using simple, familiar language
       • Using the positive rather than the negative in the stem
       • Using technical language or jargon only if it is the target of the question
       • Keeping the reading level of the item at least two grade levels below the
         formal education level of the test taker
       • Avoiding irrelevant or obscure knowledge or skill areas

7 . Avoid clues inadvertently built into the stem or response choices.


8 . Use response choices that are close in meaning to make the question more difficult
    and choices that are very different to make it less difficult.
The Question Stem


9 . Keep the stem brief but include sufficient information for the test taker to know
    what is being asked before reading the response choices.


1 0 . Try using a short sentence at the beginning of the stem to set up a scenario or
     situation, e.g., You are operating your streetcar on the 510 E line and have
     entered the tunnel to E Station. You see…

Section 23, page 23-34



11. Try to write the question in the second person, e.g., You are approaching a flashing
    amber signal…, rather than the third person, e.g., The Operator is approaching a
    flashing amber signal…
Response Choices


1 2 . Provide four response choices for each question.


1 3 . Do not repeat information in each response choice that could be included in the
      stem.


1 4 . The response choices should serve either as completions to a statement stem or as
      short replies to a question stem.


1 5 . Be sure all response choices are parallel in structure.


12. Arrange responses, if possible, in a logical order, e.g., quantitative choices
    in ascending order.
The Key Answer


1 7 . Write the key answer, i.e., the correct answer from the response choices, so that it
      provides a logical and grammatical completion of a statement stem or a logical and
      concise answer to a question.


1 8 . Keep the key similar in length, detail, and grammatical construction to the
      distractors.


1 9 . Make the response choices, A, B, C and D, the key answer an approximately equal
      number of times in a test.


2 0 . Be sure the sequence of key answers is random.
Distractors


2 1 . Keep distractors plausible and able to attract respondents who are not fully

knowledgeable or skilled.


2 2 . Use “none of the above” as a distractor only in items where there is one absolutely
      correct answer.


2 3 . Never use “all of the above” since it allows a respondent who knows only that two
      of the choices are correct to choose it.
Sensitivity


24. Avoid stereotypes and if you cannot avoid gender referents, alternate male and
    female.

Attachment D: Training Department Standard Operating
Procedure: Administration of Level One Evaluations

1.0 PURPOSE
     The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that level 1 training evaluations are
     administered, reviewed, and tracked in a consistent manner.

2.0 SCOPE



          Level 1 evaluation refers to the questionnaire survey administered to trainees in
          order to measure their reaction to a training course. The procedure is applicable to
          all courses delivered by the Training Department.



    3.0 RESPONSIBILITY


          3.1     The Manager - Training Department is responsible for ensuring that this
                  procedure is applied to all Training Department programs.



          3.2     The Training Superintendent is responsible for ensuring Instructors
                  distribute the level 1 evaluation form and follow this procedure for all
                  courses delivered in their respective areas.



          3.3     Instructors are responsible for conducting level 1 evaluations in accordance
                  with this procedure for all courses they deliver.




    3.4   The Training Clerk will set up and maintain the data on the level 1 evaluation
          results.



4.0 PROCEDURE


    ADMINISTER EVALUATIONS


    4.1   The standard level 1 evaluation (see attached) form will be used for all Training
          Department courses.



    4.2   At the start of the course, the Instructor will provide all participants with an
          evaluation form and introduce the use of the form.



    4.3   At the end of the course, the Instructor will provide detailed instructions for filling
          out and submitting the form.

4.4    The Instructor will emphasize the need for frank and honest responses and will
       guarantee anonymity for all trainees in their evaluation of the course.



4.5    The Instructor will ask for a volunteer to collect the evaluations anonymously by
       having trainees place them in an envelope which the volunteer will then seal. The
       Instructor will provide the volunteer with the envelope.




4.6    The Instructor will leave the room or training area while the trainees are filling out
       the form in order to ensure anonymity and encourage independent responses.


4.7    The Instructor will collect the sealed envelope from the volunteer and deliver it
       sealed to the relevant Training Superintendent.




REVIEW RESULTS


4.8    The Training Superintendent will review the completed training evaluation forms
       for the course.


4.9    The Training Superintendent will discuss the results of the evaluation with the
       Instructor as necessary.



TRACK RESULTS


4.10   The Training Superintendent will provide the Training Clerk with the completed
       evaluation forms on a weekly basis.



4.11   The Training Clerk will input the results into a database.

4.12   The Training Clerk will produce and distribute quarterly reports detailing
           evaluation results by program to the Manager - Training Department, the Training
           Superintendents and the Superintendent - Planning & Program Development.

       (i)     maintain structural integrity and prevent catastrophic collapse

       (ii)    maintain at least basic operating capacity in order to evacuate

       Constructability guidance on blast resistant structures design
       according to the “Structures to Resist the Effects of Accidental
       Explosions”, Army Technical Manual 5-1300/Navy Publication

•      Primary Crashworthiness. Ensuring occupants are prevented
from experiencing excessive decelerations.


•       Secondary Crashworthiness. Ensuring that any injuries caused
by: (i)    loss of survival space when the vehicle structure
collapses,
       and
(ii)   impact with interior furniture and fittings, are prevented /
