25.5.7. Fault Tree Analysis


 (a)         Fault Tree Analysis shall involve the preparation of a logic diagram,
             which traces the events or combinations of contributing events
             which have led to an undesirable occurrence (referred to as the "top
             event"). Each of the contributing event(s) shall be also considered in
             turn, together with the subsidiary events involved in those failures.


 (b)         The process shall be continued with each event being scrutinised for
             its causes until it is not practical to proceed to a lower level or the
             process need not be continued because the probability of the
             occurrence of the event is demonstrably negligible. To the most
             extent, Quantitative Fault Tree Analysis shall be prepared.
             Qualitative Fault Tree Analysis may also be used when evaluation of
             probability is based on estimation, especially in the case of human
             actions.


 (c)         Fault Tree Analysis shall be performed on those events whose failure
             consequences are classified as "Critical" or worse in accordance with

Section 26              Maintenance Requirements
26.1         General


26.1.1.      Maintenance Programme


   (a)       The Contractor shall establish and provide documentation for a
             comprehensive maintenance programme for upholding the service condition
             (refer to PS 2.1.7) of the trains. The objective of the maintenance programme
             shall be to ensure that the trains will satisfy the following requirements
             throughout their design life:


   (i )      Operational safety requirements as defined in PS 25.6
   ( i i )          Reliability requirements as defined in PS 25.7
   ( i i i )    Availability requirements as defined in PS 25.8
   ( i v )     Maintainability requirements as defined in PS 25.9
   ( v )     Quality of comfort, including cleanliness and appearance, experienced by
             passengers
   ( v i )     Minimum life cycle cost


   (b)       The maintenance programme shall cover preventive maintenance, corrective
             maintenance, cleaning, condition-based maintenance and any other activities
             necessary to maintain the trains in a condition that can fulfil the above
             requirements. Within the context of this Specification and unless otherwise
             specified, the term 'maintenance' shall include all activities covered by the
             maintenance programme.


26.1.2.      Maintenance Policy


   (a)       The maintenance programme shall be based on a planned preventive
             maintenance approach. Each train will undergo a series of regular
             maintenance sessions, the contents of which will be increased progressively in
             accordance with the amount of service and in line with the maintenance
             requirements of individual equipment. Where appropriate, condition-based
             maintenance techniques shall also be adopted to minimize the amount of
             maintenance work, downtimes and the associated costs.

(b)   Service checks and cleaning work shall be so organized that they can be
      completed within the time limits specified under maintainability requirements.


(c)   All corrective maintenance work shall be completed within the time limits
      specified under maintainability requirement.


(d)   The Contractor shall satisfy with himself on the various access restrictions as
      specified in PS 25.8.1(f) that the performance of the Works will not be

Section 26, page 26-3


          affected. The Contractor shall make his best maintenance design to minimise
          downtime and maximise the availability of the trains.


26.1.3.   Submission


          Information pertaining to maintenance requirements shall constitute part of
          the design documents to be submitted for approval.


26.2      Design for Maintenance
          The Contractor shall ensure that maintenance considerations are duly
          incorporated into the design of the train. Features that can minimize or
          facilitate maintenance shall be built into the design as integral elements. As a
          minimum, the following requirements shall be satisfied:


26.2.1.   Health and Safety


   (a)    The design of the trains shall be such that all maintenance activities can be
          carried out safely.


   (b)    The Contractor shall identify all potential hazards to personnel or equipment
          that may arise during all maintenance activities in Operating and Support
          Hazard Analyses (refer to PS 25.5.5) or similar studies. For example, the
          design of the carhouse receptacle together with the isolating and test switch
          (refer to Appendix Annex 5 Clause 6.2) shall ensure that no single point
          failure will cause any unsafe hazard to the maintainer.


   (c)    The Contractor shall establish and specify, for each potential hazard,
          corresponding preventive, mitigative or protective measures to reduce the risk
          to an acceptable level as defined in the Risk Assessment Matrix in PS 25.


   (d)    The Contractor shall ensure that all maintenance activities shall comply with
          relevant legislation in Canada regarding health and safety. For example, the
          Occupational Health and Safety Act, safety regulation 658/79.


   (e)    Testing procedures shall be built into all maintenance work to ensure that the

trains shall be restored to a safe operation condition upon completion of the
          maintenance work.


26.2.2.   Human Factors


   (a)    Ergonomic principles shall be adopted in the design of the train so that
          maintenance and cleaning activities are tailored to suit the capability and
          limitations of the maintenance staff. In general, guidelines in ISO 6385 and
          Def Stan 00-25 Parts 15-21 and Part 25 shall be adhered to. Anthropometric
          dimensions for the Canadian population shall be adopted.

          the TIMS (refer to PS 10) and YMSS (PS 18.6) plus other special tools and

26.2.5.   Line Replaceable Units (LRUs)

Section 26, page 26-6


(a)       Equipment shall be constructed in such a way that when a failure occurs, the
          train can be restored to service condition by replacing the defective equipment
          items that give rise to the failure. Such defective equipment items are referred
          to as Line Replaceable Units, or LRUs.


(b)       LRUs shall be designed for quick and easy replacement so that maintainability
          targets for corrective maintenance defined in PS 25.9 can be achieved.


(c)       In order to avoid replacing unnecessary complete higher level assemblies
          which will increase the costs in replacement, handling, reconditioning and
          spares holding, LRUs shall generally be the lowest level items in the
          equipment system which satisfy one of the following conditions:


(i)       Replacement or repair of lower level components in the item will require
          extensive stripping down and it is not practicable to design the item otherwise


(ii)      Replacement or repair of any defective part within the item can only be
          achieved with proper equipment in a workshop environment and it is not
          practicable to design the item otherwise


(d)       To give some examples, the following items shall be designed for replacement
          as LRUs:
(i )      Roof Mounted HVAC
(i i )      Contacts of specific contactors
( i i i )     Electronic printed circuit boards
( i v )     Electrical relays
( v )     Brake actuators
( v i )     Air compressors
( vi i )      Autocouplers
( v i i i )     Trucks
( i x )     Window glazing


          It is a requirement that the drop table shall be designated for the use of truck

removal / replacement only (refer to PS 25.8.1(c)).


(e)   As far as practicable, quick release connections such as plugs and adapters
      shall be provided between a LRU and the train to facilitate replacement. Relay
      connections shall be of the plug-in type such that no wire disconnection and
      reconnection are required during replacement. All quick release connections
      shall have a robust design which shall be able to accommodate LRU
      replacements throughout their design life.


(f)   LRUs mounted on the underframe, except for trucks, items on the traction
      drives and the suspension, shall be designed so that they can be replaced at the
      Running Maintenance Area of the AUTHORITY’s yards (refer to Clause 2
      and 3.5 of Appendix I Annex 5).

Section 26, page 26-7


26.2.6.     Workshop Replaceable Units (WRUs)


   (a)      Equipment which are functionally closely related shall be grouped into
            manageable physical modules, hereafter referred to as Workshop Replaceable
            Units (WRUs), to minimize the time and effort required by their replacement
            during car overhauls (refer to PS 26.3.3 ) and scheduled equipment
            replacement (refer to PS 26.3.4) sessions.


   (b)      Examples of WRUs are:


   ( i )    A pneumatic block to hold components in the compressed air system
   (i i )      A brake equipment module containing valves in the air brake system
   ( i i i )    Complete equipment cases containing contactors and relays in the traction
            inverter or auxiliary converter


   (c)      WRUs shall be designed in such a way that the time for recommissioning tests
            on the train is shortened by relocating most of the testing upstream at the
            overhaul workshop.


   (d)      Connections, other than mechanical mountings, between a WRU and the train
            shall be achieved through quick release fittings such as multi-way jumper
            plugs. Such quick release fittings shall have a robust design which shall be
            able to accommodate WRU replacements throughout their design life.


   (e)      As far as practicable, WRUs mounted on the underframe shall be designed to
            allow replacement to be carried out with the train standing at a track at the
            Running Maintenance Area. Only when this is not feasible, for example trucks,
            shall replacement be performed at a Lifting / Heavy Maintenance Area
            described in Appendix I Annex 5.


   (f)      Notwithstanding the above requirements, the design of WRUs shall allow any
            LRU which forms part of the WRU to be replaced, in-situ without replacing
            the entire WRU, within the time limit specified under relevant maintainability
            targets (refer to PS 25.9).

26.3       Preventive Maintenance


26.3.1.    Organization of Preventive Maintenance Work


           The Contractor shall establish and provide documentation for a preventive
           maintenance programme for the trains in accordance with the following
           requirements:


   (a)     Maintenance Action


           Maintenance action is defined as the smallest sub-division of maintenance
           work to be carried out in-situ on the trains, such as bearing lubrication, filter
           change and relay operation check.


   (b)     Maintenance Tasks


   ( i )   Preventive maintenance actions to be carried out in-situ on the trains shall be
           grouped into logical blocks referred to as maintenance tasks.

( i i )    The maintenance actions in a maintenance task shall be carried out together
          as a complete module. They shall either be done on the same equipment /
          equipment system, such as the collector shoe; or at the same location, such as
          saloon or driving cab.


( i i i )    Maintenance tasks shall form the basic building blocks of all maintenance
          sessions other than equipment overhauls. Low level tasks such as basic safety
          inspections shall be repeated in all preventive maintenance sessions while
          high level tasks such as truck replacement shall only be carried out at specific
          car overhauls.


(iv)      Separate tasks shall be provided to cover maintenance actions to be carried out
          at different stages of a maintenance session.

Section 26, page 26-10



(c)       Maintenance Sessions


( i )     Preventive maintenance work to be carried out in-situ on the trains shall be
          grouped into Maintenance Sessions during which a train will not be available
          for service. Maintenance sessions shall be designed to maximize availability
          and reliability while minimizing costs at the same time.


( i i )       Each maintenance session shall be divided into a number of logical work
          stages such as preparation, servicing and inspections, and recommissioning, as
          defined in PS 30. Each stage shall consist of individual maintenance tasks.


(iii)     The following types of maintenance sessions shall be provided to cover the
          maintenance requirements of trains at different service ages:


          -     Service Checks
          -     Car Overhauls
          -     Scheduled Equipment Replacements


(iv)      The minimum requirements for each type of maintenance session are specified
          in PS 26.3.2 to 26.3.4 below. The Contractor may propose alternatives to such
          arrangements for approval.


(d)       Equipment Overhauls


          Equipment overhauls refers to the following:


( i )     scheduled overhauls of individual equipment
( i i )    repair of defective equipment removed from the trains during
          corrective maintenance


          Such work shall be carried out outside the trains at the workshop with the
          required tools and equipment for the work.

26.3.2.   Service Checks


   (a)    General Requirements


   (i)    To the most extent possible and in order to reduce train movements in the
          shops, Schedule maintenance tasks and activities shall be organized with a
          minimum interval of 45 days (B-Service checks).


   (ii)   Service checks include all regular safety checks, inspections and servicing
          necessary for maintaining the trains in service condition (excluding pre-
          departure daily inspections and tests).

Section 26, page 26-11


   (iii)   The interval of B Service Checks shall be integral multiples of that for A
           Service Checks.


   (iv)    Service checks shall be designed to be carried out on complete trains so that
           each train will only be required to visit the yard once within the lowest service
           check interval. However the design of the trains and the service check
           contents shall also allow the service checks be carried out separately on
           individual units at different times.


    (b)    A Service Check


           Interval:          5,000 km (approx. 15 Days) minimum
           Downtime:Not more than 2 hours (including work arising) per car
           Location:          Running Maintenance Area (refer to Appendix I Annex 5)
           Work Content:      'A type tasks' - Checks on safety and reliability critical
                              equipment, general visual inspections, and replenishment of
                              items such as lubricants and water.


   (c)     B Service Check


           Interval:          15,000 km (Approx. 45 Days) minimum
           Downtime:Not more than 36 person-hours (including work arising) per car
           Location:      Running Maintenance Area
           Work Contents:     'A type tasks' plus items at multiples of 15,000 km intervals
                              ('B type tasks', regular scheduled maintenance)

   (a)     General Requirements

           be down for more than one Day.

be down for more than one working Day.

(iv)    The car body shall require minimal attention at overhauls. Pipework and

          cleaning methods, cleaning procedures, materials, cleaning intervals, train
          downtimes and the manpower required to carry out the work.

Section 29            Software Management

29.1     Introduction


         The purpose of this Section of PS is to define the quality and control
         requirements on all software supplied under this Contract and shall apply to
         all Subcontractors and suppliers. It covers software that are supplied as a
         stand-alone entity, as a separately identifiable part of a larger system or as an
         integral to a system being supplied. The objective is to ensure that all software
         supplied are designed structurally and logically, fully documented, thoroughly
         tested in a systematic manner such that they can achieve high quality in terms
         of safety, reliability, testability, traceability and maintainability.


29.2     Standards
29.2.1   All software supplied by the Contractor shall comply with the requirements of
         ISO/IEC 90003:2004 " Software engineering -- Guidelines for the application
         of ISO 9001:2000 to computer
         software".


29.2.2   Guidelines for the Information Security Management Systems according to
         the security standard of BS ISO/IEC 17799:2005 and BS 7799-2:2002 shall be
         followed, where applicable.


29.2.3   The software documentation generated under this Contract shall comply with
         IEEE Std 1558-2004, Standard for Software Documentation for Rail
         Equipment and Systems, and its associated IEEE software standards.


29.3     Definitions
29.3.1   The term "software" shall cover both software and firmware.


29.3.2   A software work package is defined as a group of software and/or firmware
         items which fulfil the defined requirements and shall be validated and tested

to as a Software Configuration Item (SCI).

         Contract requirements.

29.18       Software Design
29.18.1     The Contractor shall specify, in section 6.2 of the SPMP, the methods, tools
            and techniques used for the software development activities, including code of
            practice such as a coding standard. The followings present examples of
            software development design guidelines to be documented in the SPMP and
            used during software development:


(i)         The software shall follow a structured and modular design. Each program or
            module should be designed such that it can be viewed in terms of its inputs
            and outputs alone, without reference to the details of how it processes them.


(ii)        Each module should be totally independent of the particular algorithmic or
            programming techniques used in all the other modules.


(iii)       Self-modifying program will not be allowed, with the exception of
            configuration and parameter files update by the software, which shall not be
            considered as self-modifying program features.


(iv)       Header and comments shall be used to clearly specify the module and its logic.

The module size excluding comments and header should preferably not take
          up more than 150 lines of high level language or 250 lines of assembly level
          code.


( v )     Independent and separate compilation of individual modules will be allowed.


( v i )     Where structured programming techniques are used, a single entry and single
          exit point for each module shall be used. Unconditional branch statements
          shall not be used.


(vii)     All garbage codes (codes that are not executed under any circumstances) shall
          be removed.

Section 29, page 29-13



(viii)    The format of the source code shall comply with the coding standard; it shall
          be standardized, properly indented, sufficiently and clearly commented. Each
          module should have a concise introductory comment section (header)
          describing the function of the module, the algorithm used, the significance of
          important internal variables, the data structure, the call convention, the
          meaning/format of the required inputs and generated outputs.


(ix)      Constant parameters that are commonly used by different modules and those
          that require frequent tuning shall be named and defined in the global data
          definition area, instead of being incorporated into the program statements.
          They shall be referred to by name throughout the program.


(x)       The naming of variables and parameters shall be standardized and meaningful
          such that they are clearly recognizable. The Contractor shall establish a
          naming convention as part of its coding standard, submitted as part of its
          SPMP.


(xi)      Defensive programming methodology shall be employed. Validity range and
          plausibility checking on input/output parameters shall be performed. Upon
          detection of system irregularities or run-time errors, appropriate exception
          handling routines shall be invoked in order to recover the system to the
          normal operation state and a log file should be created to record the system
          status and the actions taken.


(xii)     Each module should be able to be tested separately by feeding in simulation
          parameters or signals through the external hardware interface. Diagnosis code
          should be inserted where appropriate.


(xiii)    Main and disk memory requirements should be minimized. Sub-routines that
          are shared by a number of different programs or modules should be put into
          the system library.

29.26.1   The Contractor shall define procedures to maintain the security of the

          should define the physical restrictions as well as procedural measures and
          specific tests to be carried out on the software.


(b)       Unauthorised Access


          The Contractor shall describe what measures are to be taken to protect the
          software against unauthorised access and subsequent modification. This
          description should define both physical restrictions and procedural methods.


(c)       Virus


          The Contractor shall ensure software which is susceptible to viruses is
          developed in environments certified free from computer viruses. To achieve
          this, the Contractor shall use proper virus detection software and suppression
          tools, as Approved. approval of the software tools shall not relieve the
          Contractor of its obligations to ensure that the software is free of viruses.


29.26.2   All software delivered to site shall be accompanied by evidence that
          demonstrates the media is free of viruses.

29.26.3   The Contractor shall provide a Statement of Applicability which shall identify
          all security controls and justify why they are appropriate, and show why those
          control measures according to BS7799 that have not been chosen, are not
          relevant. The Contractor shall relate the selection of the controls by means of
          risk assessment and record in the hazard log (refer to PS 25.3).

1.    General Writing Style


      Level of Detail


1.1   Technical information shall contain all of the information necessary for the user to
      perform the task involved or to comprehend a description.


1.2   The O&M Manual shall retain enough information to permit the user to perform
      the documented maintenance without error or loss of time due to insufficient
      information.


1 .   Comprehensibility


2.1   Present descriptive text in a logical order (for example, in operational sequence or
      in signal flow sequence) and include summary headers for individual paragraphs
      whenever needed for clarity.


2.2   Maintain consistent terminology, style, and format throughout the O&M Manual.


2.3   When procedural text is combined with graphics, use the following rules to
      abbreviate, so long as the meaning is not altered or obscured.


(a)   Eliminate articles.


(b)   Begin sentences with transitive verbs (action verbs).


(c)   Use the imperative mood whenever appropriate.


4.    Emphasis


      Use bold text for all words and phrases which need to be emphasised.

Note: Words that require stronger emphasis are bold and capitalised.


      Example:



      This is an optional procedure. The safety switch SHALL be set before operation.
5.    Notes and Examples


      Some guidelines to follow when using these terms are:


5.1   the word is in bold text followed by a colon
5.2   there is an indent after the colon
5.3   the first word in the text is in initial capitals
5.4   the text shall word wrap and be a hanging indent, and

Section 30, page 30-24


5.5   the label can be plural if there is more than one eg. Notes.


      Example:


      This is an example of how to present examples in an O&M manual.


6.    Aligning Notes and Examples


      Where there is a combination of notes and examples within one paragraph, they
      are to be aligned as shown below.


      Example:


             Example:         This is an example.


             Note:            This is a note.


7.    Multiple Notes


      When there is more than one point to be included as a note, the label “Notes” is to
      be used, and each note is to be numbered.


      Example:


             Notes:


             1 .      This is the first note.


             2 .      This is the second note.


8.    Spelling - Use of S/Z

In words that can be spelt using either s or z (eg. organize/organise) the letter s
     shall be used (eg. organise).


9.   Paragraphs and Sentences


     Limit paragraphs to a single idea. Limit sentences to a single thought; avoid
     compound or complex sentences. Whenever possible, limit words to those that are
     short and familiar to the target audience. Eliminate long, complex sentences and
     paragraphs through the use of lists. The resulting parallel portions of sentences
     shall be individually listed as follows:


     The beat frequency oscillator has three components:


            (1) ...

31.1      Introduction


31.1.1.   The Contractor shall perform all design duties and provide all materials,
          equipment and labour as defined in the PS to ensure satisfactory coordination
          with the equipment/systems provided by Subcontractors in accordance with
          designs which are mutually acceptable to all parties and to the approval of the
          Engineer.


31.1.2.   The Contractor shall liaise and coordinate on the interface requirements with
          the third parties including Subcontractors and statutory authorities as
          described in the PS. The Contractor shall afford the Subcontractors reasonable
          access for design data, personnel, items of plant, equipment and building
          materials.


31.1.3.   The detailed interface requirements with the Subcontractors, named suppliers
          and all third parties are described in details in Appendix I Annex 1 to Annex 6.
          Unless it is otherwise specified, no change in the existing wayside equipment
          shall be required in order to ensure compatibility between the T1 trains and
          the interfacing systems. The annexes cover the following areas:


   (a)    Annex 1 Trackwork Interface (Track Data) contains details of the track on
          which the trains will run.


   (b)    Annex 2 Third Rail Traction Power Supply System Interfaces defines the
          interface requirements for the third rail traction power supply system and the
          train system.


   (c)    Annex 3 ATC Interfaces defines the interface requirements for the SCS and
          the train system. Compatibility of the train with the existing track circuit
          system is also addressed.


   (d)    Annex 4 Communication Interfaces defines the interface requirements for all

Communications Equipment and the train system including Train Radio, VSS,
          PIS and Wireless LAN for Yard Maintenance Support System.


   (e)    Annex 5 Yard Interfaces defines the interface requirements for the yards and
          the train system.


31.1.4.   The information provided with the above Annexes are intended to assist the
          Contractor for liaison and coordination with others. As such, these
          information shall not reduce the Contractor's responsibility to ensure the
          compatibility of their Work with that of others.

2.7       Truck and Suspension


2.7.1     Truck Static Test


   (a)    The Contractor shall carry out a static proof test on a strain gauged truck to
          confirm that all the requirements of PS 12.9.3 have been achieved.


   ( b ) Strain gauges shall be placed in any area where the stress level predicted by
         FEA is greater than 80% of the yield stress or 0.2% proof stress of the
         material, and where the predicted damage over the life of the truck computed
         in accordance with PS 12.9.3(b) is greater than 0.7. The positioning of strain
         gauges shall be submitted for approval.


   ( c ) The reporting on the proof test shall include, but not be limited to, a
         comparison between the stresses measured during the proof test with those
         predicted by the FEA. In all areas where the measured stress differs from the
         stress predicted by FEA by more than 10% of the predicted value, a detailed
         explanation for the difference shall be given.


2.7.2     Truck Dynamic Test


   (a)    The Contractor shall carry out a dynamic test on the truck to demonstrate that
          the requirements of PS 12.9.3 have been achieved.


   (b)    Strain gauges shall be placed in all areas where the cumulative fatigue damage,
          evaluated in accordance with PS 12.9.3(b) is greater than 0.7.

(c)   The tests shall be carried out over a representative length of track in both
      directions at the design speed profile and shall cover all loading conditions
      from tare to crush laden.


(d)   The strain gauge signals collected during the testing shall be counted using the
      rainflow method, or other counting technique and shall be submitted for
      approval.


(e)   The results shall then be used in conjunction with the fully laden passenger
      mass given in PS 4.5.4 to assess the fatigue damage over the life of the truck.

5.1.       The running rail type is of 115 lbs/yard RE section standard carbon steel.
           Head hardened or fully heat treated rail having a Brinell hardness number of
           365 to 380 is installed on both rails of main line curved track having a radius
           less than 600m (1968.5’). At all other locations, running rail is standard
           carbon rail.


5.2.       For those curve section of central radius less than 600m (1968.5’), a
           restraining rail is installed. The restraining rail is of 100 lbs/yard A.R.A. –
           Type “A”, horizontally oriented, parallel to the running rails of a track, the
           head of which is contacted by the back of a wheel flange to hold the wheels in
           correct alignment and reduce premature wear of the high rail. Restraining rail
           is typically started on tangent track 3 m (10’) prior to the beginning of a spiral
           or circular and extend 15 m (49’) beyond the end of a spiral or circular curve.
           The restraining rail is located at a gap of 50.8 mm (2”) (minimum) to 63.5 mm
           (2.5”) (maximum) adjacent to the gauge side of the low rail i.e. inside rail.
           Such gap is also known as flangeway. For flangeway compatibility, the back
           to back wheel gauge shall be 1 475 mm ± 1.6 mm (4' 10 1/16" ± 1/16").


5.3.       For those curve section of central radius less than 600m (1968.5’), a wayside
           track lubricator is installed to reduce rail wear and noise. The lubricator is
           located at the start of a horizontal curve at the point of first full wheel flange –
           rail contact, whereas the exact contact location is site-specific depending on
           curve radius, cant deficiency and train speed. Only the gauge side of the high
           side rail and the contact face of the restraining rail will be lubricated.

2.2.   Currents will be supplied to the train by the 3 rail system and will return to

          traction system (refer to PS 11), without causing superfluous operation the 3rd
          rail system DC track feeder circuit breaker.

4. Design Constraints

4.1.     Corrosion, Moisture and Snow


4.2.1.   Equipment mounted on the train will be subjected to saline dripping which
         may include other salts that can be deposited on the collector shoe, for
         example, lime. In addition, air in tunnels carries a heavy dust content, both
         induced by the ventilation system and caused by the railway operation. The
         combination of the above will have an adverse effect on the insulation
         creepage surfaces and the life of the metal components.


4.2.2.   The general atmosphere contains a high level of industrial pollutants and salt
         spray.


4.2.3.   Top contact rails are susceptible to ice and snow contamination in cold
         climates.


4.2.4.   No lubrication of the contact material shall be necessary.

2.1.2.   Automatic Train Protection (ATP)


         The ATP system is to determine the maximum safe speed for the train and
         compare it with the actual speed. If the maximum safe speed is exceeded, the
         ATP system shall cause the emergency brake to be applied. For SCS mode
         (refer to PS 9.5) of operation, the maximum safe speed is 80 km/h (50 MPH).

3.1.   The Contractor shall ensure that all train equipment are designed and

       systems.

         specification including a Signalling Compatibility Specification. This shall
         define the levels of susceptibility and emissivity for all the trainborne
         equipment which shall guarantee compatibility.


3.5.     Equipment shall be EMC tested to the requirements of the PS. An appropriate
         technical construction file shall be developed in accordance with the EC EMC
         Directives and be certified by an appropriate Competent Body for the
         compliance of the EMC Directives.


3.6.     The following electro-magnetic disturbance sources shall be taken into
         account in the interface design:


3.6.1.   harmonics generated by rectifiers in the traction substation;
3.6.2.   main frequency harmonics in the traction supply;
3.6.3.   transients generated by switching action of the inverter controlled traction and
         auxiliary equipment;
3.6.4.   magnetic sources of the train, for example, chokes;
3.6.5.   magnetic field generates by the current in the third rail;
3.6.6.   radiated electric field from the trainborne equipment; and
3.6.7.   radiated field from the third rail.


3.7.     The Contractor shall submit a computer simulation result to predict the
         expected magnitudes of the above electro-magnetic disturbances, normal and
         fault conditions shall be considered, at SEMP stage 2, verify these simulation
         results by test during SEMP stage 3 and conduct an on-site measurement to
         validate the actual train performance by SEMP stage 5.


3.8.     The total electromagnetic interference induced by vehicle equipment to the
         ATC equipment shall be regarded as permissible conducted current on rail and
         permissible radiated emissions from train.

13.        Background


3.1        The backup battery sets on the subway, streetcar and SRT vehicle fleets
           require preventative maintenance and testing on a regular basis. This testing
           requirement is based on a current fleet size of 600 battery sets. That is 350 sets
           from subway/SRT vehicles and 250 sets from streetcars plus the battery sets
           (refer to PS 17.4.2) from the train (also known as the New Subway Train in
           this Appendix).

3.2   It is a requirement that, based on a 5 year cycle, one 8 hour shift per day and a
      5 day work week, the existing productivity of processing of a battery set on
      every 2 days shall be maintained by using the Charger.

Appendix K, page AppK-3


14.   Definitions


4.1   Battery Cell Block – In certain battery sets the cells come in 2 cell or 3 cell
      packages called Blocks.


4.2   Battery Set – A specific number of cell blocks connected together to get the
      proper terminal voltage for the vehicle type. For example, an H6 battery set
      has two 3 cell blocks and ten 2 cell blocks for a total of 26 cells.


4.3   Test Stub – The software subroutine that controls a specific function of the
      whole battery set test. For example the subroutine that governs the discharge
      process.


4.4   Charge Rates - The current that a Charger supplies to the battery is normally
      expressed as a fraction of the theoretical current (for a given battery) needed
      to charge the battery completely in 1 hour. This theoretical current is called
      the nominal battery capacity rating and is represented as “C.” For example, a
      current of 0.1 C is that current which, in 10 hours, theoretically, would
      recharge the battery fully. The required charging rates for various styles of
      recharging shall refer to the battery manufacturer’s manual.


4.5   Thermal Runaway - If the constant current is applied past the point when the
      battery reaches approximately 85% of its fully charged state, the excess heat
      will cause “thermal runaway” to occur. Under thermal runaway conditions,
      the excess heat in the battery will cause its voltage to drop. The drop in
      voltage will cause the charge rate to increase, generating more heat and
      accelerating the cycle. The temperature and internal pressure of the battery
      will continue to rise until permanent damage results.


4.6   Operator - The qualified battery maintenance personnel of the AUTHORITY.

7.3.1   State of Charge (SOC) Determination. The Charger shall be able to provide
        information of the SOC of the battery or of the individual cells in the battery

        indication of the capacity left in the battery.

7.3.2   State of Health (SOH) Determination. The Charger shall be able to provide
        information of the SOH which is a measure of a battery's capability to deliver
        its specified output. This information shall be able to aid the operator for
        assessing the readiness of the battery sets and shall be a reliable indicator of
        whether maintenance actions are needed. The acceptable way to measure the
        SOH of a battery is by impedance testing or by conductance testing . Both of
        these tests shall be carried out without discharging the battery, but the
        monitoring device shall remain in place providing a permanent on line
        measurement. This shall allow the operator to have an up to date assessment

        automatically detected and appropriate maintenance actions can be planned.


7.3.3   Cell Balancing Functions. In a battery set, small differences between cells due
        to production tolerances or operating conditions tend to be magnified with
        each charge / discharge cycle. Hence, weaker cells become overstressed
        during charging causing them to become even weaker, until they eventually
        fail causing premature failure of the battery. The Charger shall be able to
        provide battery cell balancing functions in oder to compensate the weaker
        cells by equalising the charge on all the cells in the battery set and thus
        extending battery life.


7.3.4   History Function. The Charger shall be able to provide monitoring and storing
        functions of the battery's history in order to estimate the SOH of the battery
        set. Parameters such as number of cycles, maximum and minimum voltages
        and temperatures and maximum charging and discharging currents shall be
        recorded for subsequent evaluation. This can be used as the tool to verify the
        capacity of the new subway train battery sets (refer to PS 17.4.3(h)(vi).

7.6         The Charger shall provide the discharge function. The discharge function shall
            include two modes of operation:


7.6.1       Equalization Mode


      (a)   When a battery set is to be tested and the state of charge is unknown, the
            Charger shall be able to allow the battery set to be discharged until the voltage
            across all cell falls to 1.0 Volt.
      (b)   And each cell shall not be allowed to discharge any further and shall be
            maintained at 1+/- 0.05 Volt until all other cells have reached that threshold.
      (c)   If a cell has an unexpected reaction and drops below 0.9 volts it is to be
            switched out of the circuit and the software shall indicate this state to the
            operator.
      (d)   When voltage across all of the cells has fallen to 1 Volt and the equalization
            process is complete, the initial voltage, final voltage and time to discharge for
            each cell shall be recorded in the history file as part of the history function.


7.6.2       Capacity Check Discharge Mode


      (a)   Capacity Testing. According to the battery manufacturer’s recommendation,
            the Charger shall be able to program and carry out the constant-load test in
            order to determine the capacity of a battery. This test shall be conducted by
            connecting a predetermined load to the battery and then recording the amount
            of time needed to discharge the battery to a predetermined level.


      (b)   Assuming 100% receptivity, the Charger shall be able to recycle the battery
            discharging energy back feeding to the AC line. The recycled voltage
            distortion shall not be exceeded the 5% limit as set out in the IEEE Std 519-
            1992 “IEEE Recommended Practices and Requirements for Harmonic Control
            in Electrical Power Chargers”. Monitoring device complied with the IEEE Std
            1159-1995 – “Recommended Practice on Monitoring Electric Power Quality”
            shall be provided to ensure the power quality of the recycled electricity. The
            guidelines of the power quality requirements according to the “FIPS PUB 94,
            Guideline on Electrical Power for ADP Installations. U.S. Department of
            Commerce, National Bureau of Standards”, shall be followed where
            applicable.

(c)   The operator shall be able to keep track of all cell capacities and produce an
      overall battery set capacity report based on the actual individual results. This
      report shall be viewed on screen, exported to a database file or printed to
      hardcopy, in such a way that it shall indicate the individual cell capacity and
      the resultant battery set capacity. Any cells that are below 75% capacity shall
      be flagged and announced to the operator via a graphical interface. Constant
      feedback of the test results shall be available to the operator in realtime.

      (d)   For those measured capacity of the battery set which is less than 80% of the
            rated capacity, the battery set shall be flagged as service required.


7.7         The Charger shall provide the charge function. The charge function shall

7.7.1       Service Charge Mode


      (a)   The battery set shall be charged using a constant current charging method

            that battery set type. The target voltage shall be configurable for future
            expansion. No single point failure of the Charger shall any cell be allowed to
            surpass the target voltage.


      (b)   As each cell reaches its full charge it shall be switched out of the charge
            circuit but remain monitored until all cells have reached the proper voltage.
            The Charger shall adjust the charge currents appropriately to maintain the
            manufacturer recommended charge rate on the remaining cells. If any cell
            voltage starts to decrease after it is switched out it shall be switched back in
            and brought back to the target voltage. The software shall record the time it
            took for the cell to initially reach the target voltage and record it in the history
            file and display it to the operator via the interface. When all cells reach their
            target voltage the battery set is fully charged and ready for duty. The software
            shall announce to the operator any cells that have a large variance in charge
            time from the rest of the set.


7.7.2       Capacity Check Overcharging Mode


      (a)   It is a requirement that in order to check the capacity of a battery set, it shall
            first be equalized and then overcharged. The battery set shall be charged at a
            rate corresponding to manufacturer specifications for overcharge. At the end
            of the appropriate charge time, any cell which has a voltage 20% lower than
            the target voltage shall be flagged and logged as a faulty cell. The charging
            cycle shall be considered as completed when all cells are at the proper
            terminal voltage.


      (b)   When the battery cells are disconnected from the battery set/block, the

Charger shall be able to charge all cells individually or isolate faulty cells to
         ensure one faulty cell does not stop the whole charge process.


7.7.3    The Charger shall be able to provide the following functions:
   (a)   Optimising the charging rate (a.k.a. Stabilising)
   (b)   Knowing when to stop (i.e. Terminating)

19.     Workmanship Requirements



9.1     Wiring and Cabling


9.1.1   All wiring and cabling shall be designed and installed in accordance with the

requirements outlined in this document and the National Electrical Code of
        NFPA 70 “National Electrical Code, 1996 Edition. Massachusetts, National
        Fire Protection Association”.


9.1.2   All wiring and cabling shall be run in an orderly and efficient manner. All
        unused cabling shall be removed so as to avoid air-flow obstructions and to
        allow for future installations. Orderly cabling shall minimize the potential for
        disruption due to disconnection of cables when work is taking place.


9.1.3   Whenever possible, data and power cables shall intersect perpendicularly so
        as to minimize the potential for generation of disruptive electronic noise on

Appendix K, page AppK-11


        the lines. For the same reason, it is requirement to run data and power cables
        at least 6 inches apart when they are parallel. Cables shall not be cut in place
        and left inside the cabinet or on the floor.


9.1.4   Temporary extension cords shall not be used. Proper safety precautions shall
        be taken to ensure that all jumper cable or flying lead wires which are used for
        connecting the battery set and the Charger, shall not create any tripping hazard,
        and that they shall not be damaged.


9.2     Grounding:


        All sub-assemblies or sub-racks of the Charger shall be grounded to
        grounding bus bars within the cabinet by way of copper braided ground straps.
        The grounding bus bar shall be in turn tied to the rails of the cabinet. The rails
        of the cabinet are connected to a threaded ground stud that shall be tapped
        through the case of the cabinet. The case of the rack shall be tied to copper
        detailing which runs above the cabinet. Cabinet to copper detailing
        connections shall be made by way of a copper braided ground strap. The
        overhead copper detailing shall be routed and terminated to earth ground of
        the room.


9.3     Cable Routing:


        All cable routing shall ensure separation of power, control and signal cables,
        where practicable. Since a current carrying cable radiates magnetic and/or
        electric fields and therefore is a radiating source of EMI, proper cable routing
        of these cables limits the effects of cable to cable interference coupling, shall
        be assured.




20.     Safety Requirements



10.1    The Charger shall observe, as a minimum, the following normal safety
        procedures:

10.1.1   It shall have short circuit protection.


10.1.2   It shall continuously monitor the state of the battery cells and ensure no
         overcharging takes place.


10.1.3   It shall alert the operator if the apparatus is connected incorrectly.


10.1.4   To avoid fire/explosion hazard due to spark, potential-free contact for
         controlling the Charger, shall be used.

Appendix K, page AppK-12


10.1.5   For equalizing charging, it shall be necessary to actuate a key inside the
         charger before the battery is connected.


10.1.6   The safety functions of the Charger shall prevent damage to the battery.
         Safety monitoring of the charging program shall be based on the charged Ah.
         The Charger shall be automatically switched off after more than 50% of the
         rated battery capacity has been charged, and a fault shall be displayed if this
         shall be happened.


10.1.7   Adequately rated circuit breakers shall be used to provide protection to the
         wiring and components of the Charger in the event of a short circuit or other
         condition that produces a sudden rise of current. The breakers shall be able to
         act as an on/off switch to remove power to the Charger subracks, shall any
         service work need to be done on one of these units.


10.1.8   Automatic detection circuit shall be provided, such as, temperature sensor or a
         voltage sensor, to detect when the battery is approaching the thermal-runaway
         conditions. When near the thermal runaway conditions are indicated, an alarm
         shall be issued to alert the operator and the Charger shall be automatically
         reduced or shut off the current entering the battery set.


10.1.9   The Supplier shall provide a hazard identification document for the supplied
         equipment in order to demonstrate the safety requirements are met.


10.2     Protection


         The Charger power supply inputs shall be protected against surges and
         transients occurring on the source lines. The AC/DC converter modules shall
         be equipped with inrush current limitation, over and under voltage protection
         circuits.


10.3     Earthing


         The Charger shall be designed for connection to earth ground. The internal
         subassemblies shall be strapped to the cabinet earth ground system such that

all chassis and frames have the same electrical potential at all times. During
         installation, the rack ground system shall be connected to the room grounding
         system prior to operation.


10.4     Other Safety Features


10.4.1   Connection of input power to the Charger shall strictly follow the Canadian
         electrical code regulations.


10.4.2   All exposed metal surfaces shall be grounded for personal safety. And all
         exposed metal surfaces shall be smoothed or deburred to prevent injury to

Appendix K, page AppK-13


         personnel due to contact. Surface temperatures shall not be of sufficient
         levels to cause burns or ignite adjacent materials.


10.4.3   Appropriate warning labels and covers shall be used for components and
         connections utilizing voltages in access of 85VAC. Potentials exceeding
         300VAC shall not be presented.

22.      Testing Requirements



12.1     Acceptance Testing


12.1.1   All sub-racks of the Charger shall pass the associated Factory Acceptance
         Test (FAT) to ensure correct operation. Separate FAT shall be carried out on
         each sub-racks first, then the FAT shall be completed on a fully assembled
         Charger. No FAT shall be carried out without prior approval of the associated
         FAT procedures.


12.1.2   For those sub-racks that are standard of the shelf items, they shall be tested
         independently or certified individually by the corresponding manufacturers.


12.1.3   Special test facilities and tools shall be specified in the corresponding FAT
         procedures.


12.1.4   The successful completion of an acceptance test at the Contractor’s facility
         shall be required before delivery.


12.1.5   The acceptance test shall included, as a minimum, a total cycle test of two (2)
         battery sets as supplied by AUTHORITY.



12.1.6   All functions as listed above shall be successfully verified and validated.
12.2     Charge and Discharge Modes Test


         The Charge/Discharge mode tests shall measure the ac energy consumed /
         regenerated during one charge and discharge cycle of the Charger operation.
         The power values shall be recorded during the test period at a fixed sampling
         interval, and the total duration of the test period shall be noted. The purpose of
         this test is to measure the efficiency of the Charger in a form of the extractable
         energy from the battery associated with the Charger.

12.3   On-Site Commissioning Test


       Commissioning test shall consist of a total cycle test of two (2) battery sets
       supplied by AUTHORITY. There shall then be a 30 day run-in test period
       when AUTHORITY will use the equipment to test all of it features and
       functionality. Acceptance of the Charger is subject to successful completion
       of the above tests without any major defect found.

24.       Reliability And Maintainability



14.1      Reliability


14.1.1    The MTBF for the Charger shall be 8760 hours or 3 years of operation (8
          hours per day, 365 days per year).


14.1.2    The failure rate shall be determined using the parts stress analysis method

of MIL-HDBK-217F in a ground fixed environment at 30ºC. It shall be a
         basic failure rate and therefore includes all parts serially.


14.2     Maintainability


14.2.1   For ease of maintenance and to improve the system availability, the sub-
         racks or sub-assemblies of the Charger shall be the LRU (refer to PS 26).
         Connectors shall be utilized to enable ease of installation and maintenance.
         The Mean Time To Repair (MTTR) for the Charger shall be 0.5 hours. For
         troubleshooting/maintenance purposes, any LRU can be replaced by a spare
         unit.


14.2.2   No special tools shall be required to remove or install LRUs.


14.2.3   The Charger shall be based on a proven technology that has been in use for
         a minimum of 2 years.
